Before you get defensive, let me explain.\nSIDE RANT\nHave you ever seen someone get terrible news? Their first reaction, is of course, denial. Last week, I had a horrible dream where my husband (an ICU / CC nurse working with Covid19 patients) died, alone. I remember my reaction in the dream: I shouted \u201cnoooo\u201d for about a zillion hours as I sobbed. Humans are plagued by the concept of \u201chope\u201d and once we incorporate something into our reality, whether it\u2019s a stupid conspiracy, anti-vaccination, anti-climate change, anti-anything \u201cdogmatic\u201d, our brains re-adjust that idea and incorporate it into our perception of self. We go from thinking it is true to HOPING it is true. Hoping for something to be true clouds judgment and we begin to force it to be true (whether it can be true or not) through denial, violence and shouting. Once something contradicts a paradigm (our world, our family, our beliefs, etc.), our brain has to reconcile it and sometimes, that is through persistent denial.\nWhat are your beliefs? Big and small, you associate those with the \u201cself\u201d. Are you a born again Christian? More than just an idea, right? It\u2019s a whole part of your being. Religious people like to think this is ONLY true of their faith, but sadly, it\u2019s true of all beliefs. Once we incorporate a belief as a central part of our identity, we will defend that belief \u2014even when it\u2019s manifestly wrong\u2014 to our own doom, if such a case arrives. We see this with the sad comedic morons who are the laughing stock of humanity: flat earthers. One such mentally infirm idiot just killed himself and that wasn\u2019t even a religion, it was some weird conspiracy about the curvature of the planet.\nWhat are you dogmatic beliefs? What would it take for you to change your mind? If you don\u2019t know that, figure it out. Challenge yourself and say, \u201cHow can I prove my previous axiomatic belief wrong?\u201d If you don\u2019t do that, that\u2019s not bad, it just means you\u2019re admitting that it\u2019s dogma and not a simple statement of belief. I believe aliens exist on other worlds, but that\u2019s such an unfounded belief, I would dispense with it casually as I will any belief I hold about anything in existence.\n/Side Rant\nDon\u2019t be that way.\nNo single item of food on planet Earth has a one-off metric of \u201chealth\u201d. Nothing. You need fat, but if you only eat fat, you die. You need water, but too much water will drown you. It\u2019s about the nexus point of quantity and quality over time factored against all sorts of things like your general health, sex, weight, physical exercise, age, etc. A single Snickers bar is no more unhealthy than a King Sized Reese\u2019s Peanut Butter cup. What matters is how frequently you eat it over time when judged against your caloric needs, health, weight, etc. A burger once every two weeks? Totally fine. Your body possesses the ability to process that stuff out the body, retrieve its vast amount of nutrients and get rid of the salt and calories you do not want. But if you did that daily, you\u2019d probably overwhelm that system and slowly accumulate all kinds of problems like obesity.\nPeople who like the slippery slope approach to nutrition are idiots and have no clue how physiology or nutrition works. \u201cWell, the way I figure the health quality of a food is by asking myself, \u2018if I eat this regularly, will it hurt me?\u2019\u201d which is the most idiotic way of thinking. YOUR DIET IS BASED ON VARIETY and asking yourself what it would be like if you did X every day fails the reality test \u2014 that isn\u2019t going to happen and if it did, even with healthy things, you die the same death as if you starve or eat yourself to death \u2014 deas is mother fucking dead. Sure, avoid eating whatever you like it\u2019s your body. But that isn\u2019t science. Every food item, when applied to the \u201cslippery slope fallacy\u201d becomes unhealthy. Anything in existence when taken too far, is unhealthy. Eat a candy bar once in a while. No single candy bar is healthier than the other. So I wouldn\u2019t waste my money on it. The main part of a rabbit\u2019s diet should be a good quality grass hay (timothy, orchard grass are the most common) but not a legume hay (alfalfa, clover, pea). 90% or more of their diet should be this. Then supplement with a LITTLE bit of rabbit pellets (not the kind with seeds and treats in it), 1/4 cup per 5 pound body weight of the rabbit. You can then give a very tiny bit of fresh vegetables: stick to spinach, kale, carrot tops, celery leaves, deep green lettuces and fresh grass. But only give a little, maybe 1 spinach leaf or a 2 by 3 inch leaf, no more, and only a few blades of grass per day to start. Rabbits are like horses, and if they get too many carbs they will bloat and colic and die a horrible death. If you just have to, you could give one nickel of carrot slice per day, but more has too much carbs. Fat rabbits are not healthy rabbits, and unhealthy rabbits have tummyaches.", "Iceberg lettuce has very little nutritional value and is mostly water and fiber. I really wouldn't recommend it for rabbits, there are plenty of much better vegetables they can eat.", "I don\u2019t think there\u2019s any \u201callowed\u201d or \u201cnot allowed\u201d foods (except for lots of cruciferous vegetables that can give them gas). It\u2019s better to spend a little more and get your rabbit green leaf lettuce.", "Rabbits are primarily grazers, who rely on eating grasses so giving them too much of any lettuce is never a good idea.\nBut iceberg lettuce contains lactucarium and this can be harmful to rabbits. So iceberg and other pale coloured lettuces should be avoided for rabbits. And there\u2019s another reason to skip them too. They have so much water in them, they\u2019re almost devoid of useful nutrients.\nThe basis of the diet for any rabbit is fresh, clean, non dusty hay and they need hay in front of them 24/7. This helps to mimic natural foraging so they don\u2019t get bored and it\u2019s coarse enough to wear down those teeth.\nSome dark leafy greens are nice addition to the hay, but not in huge amounts. The darker the green, the better & the more fibrous the better. Romaine\u2019s probably the best lettuce. Try kale too. I\u2019d bet that microgreens ( sprouts) would be eagerly accepted too. Rabbits relish tender new growth, so broccoli or radish sprouts, etc, would be good.\nIntroduce greens gradually to avoid upsetting the digestive system.\nRemember that large amounts of lettuce, especially if the rabbit is not used to it, cause digestive upsets.\nCarrots and any other roots and fruits, are strictly for the odd treat and should never be regular menu items, never mind Bugs Bunny\u2019s example."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Neive O'Dwyer", "view_list": [77, 5, 99, 213]}, "849": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Reynold Conger"], "question_title": "What happens to all the honey in the bee hive if humans or animals don't harvest/eat it?", "topic_list": ["Honey Bees", "Apiculture (Beekeeping)", "Honey", "Bees (insect)", "Entomology", "Insects", "Eating", "The Human Race and Condition", "Animals", "Food"], "no_of_view": "783", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [2], "ans_list": ["A good portion of the honey produced during the summer is eaten by the bees during winter. If there is honey left over, such as when no honey is harvested,the honey simply accumulates from year-to-year. In some cases this leads to extremely large hives containing huge stores of honey, but in most cases the stores of honey take away living space and the hive becomes crowded.\nWhen the bees feel crowded they prepare to swarm. The nurse bees act as though the Queen died and prepare to rear a new Queen. This is done by selecting as many as a dozen of the youngest larvae usually only a couple of days old. The selected larvae are fed extra royal jelly which stimulates various hormonal changes in the body of the larvae that lead to the larvae developing into Queens. Meanwhile the nurse bees building extra-large cells around the growing Queen bees.\nA few days before the new batch of queens hatches, about half the bees and the hive and the old Queen fill their stomachs with honey because they do not know where their next meal will come from. They then take flight and fly anywhere from 100 yards to 1 mile until they come to rest upon an object such as a tree limb. They cluster together into a ball about the size of a soccerball and rest. Meanwhile scouts are looking for a new home for the swarm. When the scouts report that they have found a suitable cavity for a new hive, they lead the entire swarm to this new cavity where a new hive is built.\nMeanwhile back at the old hive, the first Queen bee to hatch becomes the new Queen. She takes a mating flight during which she is impregnated by several drones, usually from other colonies. Then she settles down to her task of laying up to 2000 eggs per day rest of the be settle down to their usual tasks in the, money settles down to his usual routine except that it now only has half the population it used to have. It will take the rest of the year building up its population normal strength."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Dreezy Mida", "view_list": [544]}, "159": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How do I make white sauce?", "topic_list": ["Meringue", "Sauces", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "89", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Sneha Arora", "view_list": []}, "46": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Why is the Air Force chow food so much better than the other military branches?", "topic_list": ["Military Branches", "Military Education and Training", "Soup", "U.S. Air Force", "Air Forces", "Indian Air Force (IAF)", "United States Armed Forces", "Cooking", "Military", "Food"], "no_of_view": "147", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Manny Santos", "view_list": []}, "604": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Magnar Nordal", "Jacque Scott"], "question_title": "Can you eat boiled eggs while detoxing?", "topic_list": ["Hard-boiled Eggs", "Detoxification", "Eggs (food)", "Healthy Eating", "Food"], "no_of_view": "1,309", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Yes, but detox cures are worthless. See this answer:\nJ Martin's answer to Does olive oil come from black or green olives?", "It has little to do with freshness. Most olive oils are made from a mix of both green and black (ripe) olives. The green olives give a stronger flavour, whilst the black olives give mildness and subtlety to the overall flavour. There are olive oils that are made from only green olives, but these are quite rare. These oils will have a very strong, somewhat acidic, flavour, whereas the blended varieties will be much more palatable to most tastes."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Diane Sanders", "view_list": [2, 70]}, "630": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 5, "name_list": ["Devin Carroll", "Meg Osterby", "Michael Kitmura", "Cary Voss", "Salma Akter"], "question_title": "How do I kill or get rid of maize beetle inside a sack of corn?", "topic_list": ["Beetles", "Corn", "Insects", "Food"], "no_of_view": "269", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Organic grain producers mix their grains with food-grade diatomaceous earth. Adult females will start laying eggs almost immediately so once you have some activity in a structure, its sure to blossom into a problem which will need attention.\nFound throughout the world, Maize Weevils are a pest which can be controlled like many other pantry pests. "613", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["Foods that have perishable dates are given such as a safe barrier against the inevitability of microorganisms to induce chemical, and enzymatic changes in foods,that could make you sick from food poisoning,the most common being salmonella,and a handful of other contaminants.Taking foods out of temperature too long,or on an unsafe surface, puts them past what are known as critical control points.This is established by National health codes under the HACCP program and relegated to State control for such industries as wholesale food distribution,and guidelines for hospitals to follow.One way to follow these rules at home is to first keep food surfaces clean and sanitary,including utensils needed.After that, it's important to monitor your own refrigerator with the controls provided,or a hanging thermometer inside your fridge.Then remove perishable foods to preparation areas,and inspect raw,or perishable foods by washing vegetables thouroghly and inspecting containers for leakiness,cleanliness or damage,if such damage exists,inspect the refrigerator for cross contamination, inspect other foods or containers Fermentation works best at about pH 4.5, acidic, but not crazily so. Lemon juice, on the other hand, is just over 2, which is acidic enough to discourage the bacteria and yeast used in fermentation.\nBut if the soup is already made, the fermentation has occured. So it would be like drizzling lemon juice over a pickle, or adding it to sauerkraut. It just happened. We as children preferred sitting at the \u201ckids table\u201d because there we could have conversations we could relate to and we could goof around. Something our mothers would\u2019ve kept us from doing had\u2019ve we sat at the table with her. To us. The \u201cgrown-ups table\u201d just looked rather \u201cboring\u201d. To say the least. When one of us as children had one day decided to sit at the \u201cgrown up table\u201d, while the other kids were sitting at the \u201ckids table\u201d. We were instructed that \u201cThe kids sit over there\u201d. But this only happened during family holiday get togethers. When we had hit a certain age. I\u2019d say high school aged. It didn\u2019t matter to the adults what table we sat at.", "If there were enough people at once, then yes. I\u2019ve never bothered to set up a 2nd table at my house. Kids and adults come and go at the 1 table. Some people prefer the living room. Kids almost never want to sit at a table as omg as an adult when they\u2019re little anyway", "Yes\u2026we always got a kids table\u2026.I preferred sitting with the adults as it was more interesting", "Yes.\nWe had Thanksgiving with our 6 cousins, their parents, my grampa, and Uncle John, alternating between our house and my aunt\u2019s. Their were 9 in my family. No one\u2019s table could accommodate that many people, so we had a kids\u2019 table and a grown-up table. In the years we were at home, we all ate at once at two tables. In the years we were at my aunt\u2019s we ate in 2 shifts.\nThat\u2019s also what a real family does.", "Yes", "Since my husband and I have the biggest home, when we had extended family dinners the kids got to sit at the kitchen table without having the adults telling to behave all the time. That was all she needed; she said we were a boring bunch so she preferred to sit at The Cool Kids table from then on! The TV was switched off, everybody (except the old aunts) would get up and give my mother a hand with laying the table and bringing plates of food to the table, and at the end we kids would also clear the table and do the washing-up. You can do it very slow at 300 degrees and it will take 7\u20138 hours. If you use a temperature of 350 degrees, it will shave a couple of hours off the cook time. The main thing is to have some water to transmit the heat to the tissues and break them down.", "Normally I braise beef to be shreded. It can be braised on the stove top or in the oven but the method is the same: First salt and brown the beef (something like a chuck roast) in some canola oil in a dutch oven or a fairly heavy pot with a lid. Then add beef broth to roughly half cover the beef, put the lid on and bring the liquid to a boil on the stove. Then continue to simmer it on the stove or put it in a 350\u02da to 375\u02da oven for around 2 hours, maybe a little more. Check it by using 2 forks and try shreding it. If it shreds pretty easy it is ready, if not, it needs more time. Shred it while it is still pretty warm. You can then make whtever you want to make with it or let it cool and seal it up (so it doesn\u2019t dry out) and put it the frig to make your dish when you are ready.", "It sounds like you are wanting to make \u2018pulled beef\u2019 (which can also be used with other meats such as chicken or pork.)\nUsually the easiest thing is to buy a \u2018slow cooker\u2019 and put the meat in it for about 6 hours. All milk-producing mammals (yes, including humans) produce milk with the A2 beta casein protein, except certain cows that were bred for an increased milk production. This breeding may have introduced a gene mutation, causing them to produce A1 milk. That would explain why goat\u2019s milk doesn\u2019t cause you a problem. Be careful\u2026 that grease can be hotter than hades as it wicks into the paper towel!", "If you are going to use the browned hamburger in a casserole, chili, stew or something else with liquid then here's what I would do since fat floats on water.\nPut your browned hamburger into a watertight heat proof container like a Pyrex measuring cup. Something tall and narrow like a soup can would be preferred over something shallow and wide like a frying pan.\nPour just enough over the browned hamburger to come up half an inch above. Give the mixture of stir and wait a few minutes then skim the fat off the top. The hot water will dissolve the fat from the surface of the brown hamburger chunks and it will float to the top.\nSkim the fat off the top then season and use the whole mixture in your chili, casserole or stew.\nIf the hamburger is not going into a soup or stew then you might try centrifugal separation. This is how commercial snack makers create reduced fat potato chips.\nLine the basket of your salad spinner with paper towels then add your cooked hamburger to the basket. Give it a quick spin and most all of your grease will fly off onto the paper towels.\nSome people will not want their hamburger to touch a paper towel, that's fine with me. Just thought I would mention it.", "After browning it, you can pour it into a colander and run extremely hot water over it, or you can blot the meat (again, after browning) with paper towels to remove the grease.", "Do not season at first. Start browning it, and when the meat is about halfway done, and still has a good amount of pink, drain if whatever fat has accumulated, and rinse it thoroughly. Put it back in the pan and season as you normally would. You will cook off the water left from rinsing, and may have to drain again, but it will be as if you bought a leaner meat in the first place.", "Fry it up, then you can either use a spoon to scoop off the extra grease or use a spatula to keep the meat from falling and pour it off into a mason jar."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], Sterols are steroid alcohols and are an important class of organic molecules that occur naturally in plants. They are linked to reduced LDL cholesterol (the bad cholesterol) levels in our bodies. Kaempferol\nis a strong antioxidant that helps to prevent oxidative damage to our cells, lipids, and DNA. In fact, popular powdered stevia sweeteners go through dozens of steps during processing from bleaching to chemical alteration\n.\nThere are two compounds in stevia that are responsible for the sweetness: Stevioside and Rebaudioside A.\nRebaudioside A is most often extracted and used in stevia powders and sweeteners, but it is not usually the only ingredient. In fact, most stevia sweeteners on the market contain added erythritol from corn, dextrose or other artificial sweeteners.\nStevioside only makes up about 10% of the sweetness in stevia but also has the unusual bitter aftertaste that many people don\u2019t like in stevia. It also contains most of the beneficial properties of stevia that are credited with the health benefits and is the most well studied.\nTo answer this question, it is important to differentiate between processed forms of stevia and the naturally occurring herbal form\n.\nStevia as the green plant that you can grow in your backyard or find as dried leaf or tincture form is considered safe and has even been studied and found to have health benefits.\nPowdered and bleached stevia, though FDA approved, has not been studied and undergoes an extensive chemical process to reach its final white powdered form\n.", "Stevia is a herb leaf which is sweet in taste. So as stevia if it's consumed in the limit it won't harm.", "Stevia is a natural sugar and sweetener substitute\nthat is extracted from the leaves of the plant species Stevia rebaudiana (which is a member of the chrysanthemum family). It is believed to have originated in Paraguay. It has zero calories, no carbohydrates and a glycemic index of zero.\nThere are generally three main types of stevia you can purchase: green leaf stevia (the least processed option), stevia extracts and altered stevia (like Truvia). You can use stevia to replace sugar in baking. With stevia, a little goes a long way. It is reportedly 100-300 times sweeter than table sugar.\nSounds too sweet to be true.\nLet\u2019s look more into the benefits of this natural sweetener.\n\u201cAlthough Stevia can be helpful to anyone, there are certain groups who are more likely to benefit from its remarkable sweetening potential. These include diabetic patients, those interested in decreasing caloric intake, and children. Stevia is a small perennial shrub that has been used for centuries as a bio-sweetener and for other medicinal uses such as to lower blood sugar,\u201d according to the National Institutes for Health\n(NIH).\nA 2010 study by the NIH found evidence that stevia lowered glucose and insulin levels in both lean and obese people. Recently, researchers\nexplained in some detail how stevia controls blood sugar levels. Study participants also reported to feel full and satisfied despite a low calorie intake.\nIn addition to this, a 2009 study\nsuggests stevia may help lower cholesterol.\n\u201cResults of intervention revealed that stevia extract intervention had positive and encouraging effects over lipid profile. No adverse effect was observed on the health status of the subjects and it can thus be concluded that the stevia extract intervention is effective in lowering the elevated levels of serum cholesterol, triglyceride, low density lipoprotein and very low density lipoprotein levels and increasing the HDL levels,\u201d according to study notes.\nIn addition to this, several studies report stevia is rich in anti-inflammatory compounds and antioxidants that may help prevent cancer. It may even have antimicrobial properties and help fight bad bugs and infection.\nJust because a substance is natural does not mean it is safe. And there are some reported downsides to stevia.\nMost importantly, you have to be mindful of what stevia products you buy. Not all of them are created equal. Truvia, for example, has been reported to be chemically processed. Other stevia products may have sugar mixed in them in order to help mitigate some of the bitterness of natural stevia. So it\u2019s important to look for \u201c100 percent pure stevia extract\u201d on the label, not \u201cstevia powder.\u201d To learn more about additives often added to many stevia products on the market, click here\n.\nThere is also an NIH report\nthat suggested stevia may inhibit the growth of good bacteria in the gut.\nStevia may also interact with medications you may be taking, particularly medications you may be taking for diabetes, blood pressure and cancer. Talk to your doctor if you have any health issues and are interested in adding stevia to your diet.\nAt the end of the day, if you do use stevia it is probably a good idea to consume it in moderation.\nRemember, a little goes a long way.\nSource: Name Your Sweetener. Mainly because it is seen to be a safe, natural alternative to other sweeteners on the market \u2026 intensely sweet, yet with a low GI. However, not all Stevias are created equal - so it might be worth investigating the brand that you use to ensure it really is the right sugar substitute for you. For more information, check out this informative article:\nIs Your Stevia Safe? \u2013 Rebecca Rychlik \u2013 Medium", "It is safe but I find its taste incredibly gross. I've tried it several times and cannot get past its horrid taste.\nIt is the sugar molecules extracted from a certain plant that has sweet leaves called the Stevia plant", "Stevia is called as natural sweetner and an alternative to sugar. Stevia is a plant that is typically grown in South America, and while its extract is 200 times sweeter than sugar, it does not raise blood insulin levels. That\u2019s what makes it so popular.\nStevia has many health benefits like,\n\u2022 It can help reduce blood pressure for patients with mild hypertension.\n\u2022 It reduces blood sugar and avoids other types of cancer growth.\n\u2022 It as an alternative for sugar, and simply avoiding sugar can have health benefits of its own.\nYou may buy Stevia Tablets/sachets online from brands like,\n\u2022 Sweetleaf\n\u2022 Gaia Lite Stevia sachets, Tablets\n\u2022 Pure Via\n\u2022 NuNaturals\n\u2022 Stevia in the Raw", "The FDA has not approved all stevia. In December 2008, the FDA issued a no-objection letter affirming and supporting the safety of stevia leaf extract, a well-characterized, high-purity ingredient derived from the best tasting parts of the stevia leaf. Published safety studies have demonstrated that stevia leaf extract had no effects on general health, reproduction, fertility, growth, or development. Stevia leaf extract is generally recognized as safe for use in foods and beverages for use as a general purpose sweetener.\nKnow more visit\u2026..Stevia", "Stevia doesn't cause cancer or obesity.", "Yes Stevia is Safe & natural Sweetener Product.\nIt doesn\u2019t cause any issue like obesity and Cancer in Human.\nTo more info read STEVIA CULTIVATION\nThis Blog.\nor mail at info@aciagro.com", "A recent study commissioned for a BBC television programme suggested that stevia could be one of the safest artificial sweeteners. The problem with aspartame and saccharin is that they seem to raise blood glucose levels, which is not good for anyone with diabetes. Stevia and, I think, cyclamate, are thought not to do this. The BBC research tested stevia against aspartame but was not large enough to give a definitive answer. However, the results of the research were sufficiently strong to justify further research and convince me that the unverified observations about various sweeteners are probably true. I have decided to give stevia a go.\nI had bought stevia in the past but thought it tasted disgusting. Recently, I saw Canderel stevia tablets with \u201cnew, improved flavour\u201d written on the pack. They taste slightly different to Canderel aspartame tablets but they are definitely acceptable to my tastebuds.\nAs others have said, there\u2019s no evidence that approved artificial sweeteners do anything other than sweeten your drinks. The testing regime in all developed countries is very rigorous and I do trust them. The possibility that saccharin and aspartame could raise blood glucose is a fairly recent observation and has not yet been confirmed. For most people, this doesn't really matter but it would help diabetics to switch to stevia or cyclamate if further research confirms the early studies. It might be worth changing if there\u2019s diabetes in your family, even if you don\u2019t have it. Otherwise, like me, you might just be curious to see what it tastes like. It\u2019s not a shortage of animal problem, it\u2019s a supply chain problem.", "The answer to your question has more to do with the supply chain than demand at this point. We have a bottle neck and slaughter facilities right now because COVID-19 affected the workers. These plants/farms run with very little margin for the process to slow down. If animals aren\u2019t being slaughtered, we will run out of room quickly. The livestock doesn\u2019t stop growing just because the slaughterhouse stops, and can quickly grow too large for the slaughter facilities. It\u2019s breaking people..", "There is a progression from Farmers field to feedlot to abbatoir to meat packer to butcher to shopper to delivery.\nWith much of the meat processing capacity shut down due to worker illness, animals already in the feedlot to abbatoir phase of the process have nowhere to go, the current custodians have no funds to keep them, and the conditions they are in are not suitable for long term keeping of animals.\nThey can't be kept where they are at, there's already no room for them where they came from, and they can't be processed.\nOptions are limited.", "Simple: cows, pigs, chickens and more don\u2019t come in bite-size chunks. They come in their original full-sizes. A steer may weigh in at 1000 lbs and have over 400 lbs of meat.\nThat juicy t-bone you enjoy, or even the ground chuck is the result of a cattle (often still living) going in one end of a processing plant, killed, cut up, and coming out at the other end of the plant in chunks that can be easily sold and shipped and either used intact or cut down further at your local butcher shop.\nChickens go in by the 1000s and get their viscera removed, defeathered, deboned, and again come out the other end as legs, breasts, wings, chunks, etc.\nLittle to none of this can be done by your local butcher, grocer, food bank or restaurant (some butchers and restaurants have the equipment and training to butcher large pieces of animals, but generally not the initial slaughter of them)\nThe impending crisis the US is facing is processing plants that are capable of this are being shut down due to larger numbers of workers coming down with Covid-19. This means they can\u2019t safely work. If the plants can\u2019t operate, the meat can\u2019t be processed and most likely will be wasted.\nFortunately, based on my laymen\u2019s understanding of how the virus is transmitted and the fat that pretty much all the meat I eat is cooked, which is known to kill the virus, I\u2019m not worried about the processing plants transmitting the disease. But without enough workers, they\u2019ll close, for at least some period of time.\nSo, unfortunately, the animals will most likely go to waste, but it will most likely be a short-term disruption and we\u2019ll get through it just fine. I would plan on a few more meatless meals over the next few weeks, but that\u2019s probably a good idea anyway."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Lyra Minute", "view_list": [13, 10, 45, 51, 76]}, "98": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "error", "topic_list": ["error"], "no_of_view": 0, "create_time": "", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "", "view_list": []}, "599": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Steven Haddock", "Luke Nema"], "question_title": "When and why did humans decide to cook most of their food (boil, fire)?", "topic_list": ["Boiling", "Food Science", "Fire", "Anthropology", "Humans", "Eating", "Cooking", "The Human Race and Condition", "History", "Food"], "no_of_view": "665", "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "upvote_list": [2, 1], "ans_list": ["Although it\u2019s uncertain how long it\u2019s been since humans (or pre-humans) started using fire, it\u2019s very clear that soon after they controlled fire they used it for cooking and not just heating.\nEstimates of when humans were first able to control fire (that is, create it on demand and not just taking advantage of existing fire) range from 200,000 years ago to 1.7 million years ago.\nBut the archeological evidence of cooked meat over fire is clear - it first happened 2 million years ago.\nAnd the reason is that cooked meat tastes better, is easier to chew, is easier to cut with knives, has fewer pathogens and actually can last until the following morning before you eat it. Raw unrefrigerated meat pretty much has to be eaten fresh. Cooked unrefrigerated meat will last several hours.\nBoiling, on the other hand, is a more recent development. That required a vessel that you could put in the fire that would hold water. However, before that, foods could be cooked by putting them in a skin, pottery or basket that was watertight and adding hot stones. This could get water up to 60 Celsius. This method was still in use in the Americas when Europeans arrived with iron pots, which were a hot commodity.", "The true answer may never be known, but the theory I have heard is that likely not long after fire was discovered people tried to burn an animal, possibly as a sacrifice possible out of curiosity. That's what makes it so delicious, and what gives it that soft, ethereal crumb. Brioche is not a laminated dough, the butter is mixed into the dough until it is fully incorporated. Plain white bread, if it's a lean dough made with flour, water, yeast and salt, has much less fat. White sandwich bread, which is made with dairy, eggs and fat, may or may not be healthier, depending on the recipe.\nAs to it's being healthier than white bread, it depends on what you consider healthy, what type of white bread you're comparing it to, and how much and how often you eat brioche. Or white bread, for that matter. No bread, or any particular food, is inherently unhealthy, as long as it is eaten in moderation as part of a sensible diet.\nSupermarket sandwich breads, even the whole grain varieties, often contain things people prefer to avoid, like dough improvers, preservatives, and added sugar. A good brioche won't have those additives, though many bakeries use dough improvers to get better rise and inproved texture in their bread. But it will have lots of fat, in the form of butter. How much you want to consume is up to you. The occasional brioche breakfast roll isn't going to do you any harm, as long as you bslance it with other things, but neither will the occasional slice of white bread. Eating either to excess is bad for you.", "Not unless you consider butter, in excessive amounts, to be a healthy ingredient.\nIs seems that you don't know how brioche is made. Let me describe to you the way that French chefs make brioche.\nFirst they make s rich bread dough. They roll out onto s rectangle. While it rests, they take a full pound of sweet butter and pound and roll it into a rectangle about 1/3 the size of the dough.\nThen, they carefully put that rolled butter onto the middle of the pastry, then they fold each end over the middle and roll it into a rectangle again. It's then wrapped on plastic and put onto the fridge for 30 minutes, to allow the dough to relax and the butter to firm.\nAfter 30 minutes, it's removed from the fridge, rolled into a rectangle, and the two ends are rolled across the middle. Then, it's back to the fridge to cooln and gmhsrden the butter. Again.\nThis process is treated and treated until enough layers of butter have been formed if memory serves, it end up with more than 1000 layers of butter\nAre that point, it's cut and shaped until so many things, including the crescent shape that's commonly called a \u201ccroissant\", named for the crest on the Moorish flag baked by the Viennese bakers who initially made this lovely French pastry in order to celebrate the fact that their army had defeated the Moorish advance into Vienna.", "No. Brioche contains a high amount of carbs and fat, and is not any healthier than white bread."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Daniel Guerra", "view_list": [8, 214, 97, 6]}, "24": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Swati Sharma", "Tarun Naskar"], "question_title": "What is the best recipe for litthi chokha?", "topic_list": ["Litti Chokha Recipe", "Recipe Recommendations", "Indian Recipes", "Easy Recipes", "Baking Recipes", "Cuisine", "Indian Cuisine and Food", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "365", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Try to cook litti in appam pan n for recipe refer to hebbars kitchen \u2026.", "There isn\u2019t any \u2018best\u2019 recipe for Litthi-Chokha. In fact, bananas could help fill you up a lot better than other higher-calorie snacks. However, they aren't quite as filling as some other fruits. There isn't any evidence that bananas contribute to weight gain or weight loss. Instead, it's important to realize that bananas have calories, and calories add up. At the same time, simply adding bananas to what you are already eating adds calories that can lead to extra pounds in time. Bananas are high in many nutrients and provide many health benefits. They contain lots of fiber, carbs, and some essential vitamins and minerals. Bananas also contain a number of beneficial plant compounds and antioxidants, including dopamine and catechin. Unripe, green bananas are high in starch and resistant starch, while ripe, yellow bananas contain mostly sugars. Resistant starches are long chains of glucose (starch) that are resistant to digestion. They act like soluble fiber in the body and have lots of potential health benefits. This includes weight loss and reduced blood sugar levels. Resistant starch can also slow down the absorption of sugar from foods. This keeps your blood sugar levels stable and helps you feel full."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Catherine Doucer", "view_list": [64, 82]}, "823": Here\u2019s how to go about this:\nAll you need is:\n\u00b7 2 bananas, cut into half\n\u00b7 1/4th cup creamy peanut butter (let this sit out so that it's not too jammed up)\n\u00b7 1/4th cup dark, milk or white chocolate (play with your palate \u2013 or your little ones)\n\u00b7 1/3rd cup Rice Power Cereal Mix from Gouri\u2019s Goodies\n\u00b7 4 craft sticks (or popsicle sticks, if you have them)\nMethod:\n1. Insert a popsicle stick into each banana piece and spread each with peanut butter. This is a fun one for the kids \u2013 with their child-friendly knives!\n2. Place them on a lined baking tray and let them freeze for about 15 minutes until solid.\n3. Melt the chocolate until then.\n4. Very easy to prepare and crumble in the mouth goodness \u2013 make sure to add this to the kid\u2019s cooking list.\nAll you need is:\n\u00b7 225 gm butter\n\u00b7 3/4th cup sugar\n\u00b7 125 gm of flour\n\u00b7 1 tsp vanilla\n\u00b7 70 gm ground almonds\nMethod:\n1. It is done for two reasons. It avoids the thin layer of meat around the end of a bone from burning and tainting the dish and it cuts the sinew and tidies up the bone to prevent the meat contracting and toughening. It has nothing to do with steak.\nA steak should never contain a bone that extend outside the body of the cut or has a sinew attached to it. Before you respond about a tomahawk steak. That is a secondary cut that they are trying to sell you as a primary cut.\nIf you want to french a cut the best in my opinion is a lamb shank. It can be frenched to release the sinews running to the foot and provide a nice clean bone. I prefer to just cut around the bone to release the sinews.", "I assume frenching means in a french style (and not thounge kissing it).\nFirst, the french never talk about steak. When the french are frenching it it is all about cuts. If they say beef or bifteck they usually mean a strip steak or New York strip, usually with the fat left on. If you see a menu item called boeuf minute or steak minute you will get a thinnish strip steak hastily done with fries and a sauce bearnaise or a spiced butter.\nSauce bearnaise or an aromatic butter, usually parsley, shallots, herbs or cafe de Paris are the most common with steak, but if they have sauce bordelaise, go for it. it is a dense red wine sauce thickened with bone marrow\nThe french do not have anything called gravy.\nThe most common piece of meat in France will be the entrecot, what americans call rib eye.\nServed on the bone it is called cote de boeuf. It is usually hastily browned and finished of in the oven to the desired degree of doneness\nLastly, tenderloin is called filet and is sold as filet mignon meaning the smaller parts, coeur de filet - the middle part, or chateaubriand - the thickest part.\nA classic way to serve tenderloin is to do it in provencal style, in one piece on top of sliced potatos and served with garlic butter and chopped roasted hazelnuts", "The only cut I am familiar with would be the ribeye with the bone not cut short. When it\u2019s frenched, you have a Tomahawk steak.\nWhat to Know About Frenching a Bone", "Don\u00b4t understand the question. Frenching is a technique of cleaning up the bone of beef ribs or lamb racks etc\u2026.."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Diane Sanders", "view_list": [56, 484, 29, 4]}, "528": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Can salmon roe be refrigerated and microwaved?", "topic_list": ["Salmon", "Microwave Ovens", "Refrigeration", "Fish", "Food"], "no_of_view": "304", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Veni Johanna", "view_list": []}, "479": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 12, "name_list": ["Ken Chung", "Deborah Geyer", "Neal Elkind", "Frank Mendoza", "Gordon Allen", "Bryan Lucas", "Mikhail Yurievitch Yakunkin", "Joseph Granese", "Saul Goad", "Karl Eberhart", "Peter Smith", "Jeff Clark"], "question_title": "What did Russian soldiers eat during WW2?", "topic_list": ["Russian Soldiers", "Military Personnel", "World War II", "Russia", "Eating", "Military", "Military History and Wars", "History", "Food"], "no_of_view": "15,117", "create_time": "Mar 23, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 2, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["Before the outbreak of Great Patriotic War, the rations provided to a Soviet soldier was actually quite good (on documents\u2026) :\nRye bread (800 grams in April-September, 900 grams in October-March)\nWheat flour (20 grams)\nGroats (140 grams)\nMacaroni (30 grams)\nMeat (150 grams)\nFish (100 grams)\nSoybean powder (15 grams)\nAnimal fat (30 grams)\nVegetable oil (20 grams)\nSugar (35 grams)\nBlack tea leaves (1 gram)\nSalt (30 grams)\nVegetables: potatoes (500 grams), fresh or fermented cabbage (170 grams), carrots (45 grams), beetroot (40 grams), onion (30 grams), cucumbers or another type of green vegetables (35 grams)\nKetchup (6 grams)\nBay leaves (0.2 grams)\nPeppers (0.3 grams)\nVinegar (2 grams)\nMustard powder (0.3 grams)\nOf course, things changed after the outbreak of the war, especially after the German occupation on Ukraine where the Soviets produced and stored most of their food for Western USSR. The basic rations usually included:\nDried fish (protein, sodium and fat)\nSmoked sausage (for more protein, sodium and fat, a bit more like a luxury)\nNot less than 400 grams of rye bread (carbohydrate)\nShchi (\u0449\u0438), which means cabbage soup. (Vitamins and minerals, surely not that appetizing and colorful)\nIf the field kitchen units were responsible for a meal to a battalion or division, and food supply was not that harsh, there would be like these:\nKasha (\u043a\u0430\u0448\u0430), which means porridge. (barley, buckwheat or oat)\nKulesh (\u043a\u0443\u043b\u0435\u0448), millet porridge with vegetables (again, not that colorful)\nBorshch (\u0411\u043e\u0440\u0449)\nTushonka (\u0442\u0443\u0448\u0451\u043d\u043a\u0430), canned stewed meat (beef and pork for most of the time), they were eaten with boiled potatoes, buckwheat kasha or bread as sandwich.\nSometimes, soldiers were served with hot tea from a samovar (\u0441\u0430\u043c\u043e\u0432\u0430\u0440).\nFor the pilots of the air force, their rations were far more better than most Soviet soldiers and provided more energy. They had all items that an ordinary infantryman received for rations, and items that an infantryman would seldom have, including fresh or dried fruit, fresh or condensed milk, cottage cheese, sour cream, eggs, butter and cheese.\nFor the navy personnel, as they could seldom get fresh vegetables and meat, they relied on fermented vegetables, pickles, raw onions for minerals and vitamins (to prevent scurvy), canned meat like corned beef, pork, fish for protein. For vessels, they had ovens to bake fresh breads and some had stoves for real dishes. For submariners, they relied on Rusks (twice-baked bread) for carbohydrate (to save oxygen from cooking inside a submarine). Red wine and cottage cheese would also be served for submariners as their great casualty rate (> 80%) for the well-being of mother Russia deserved better food for them.\nWell\u2026\u2026..this war was famous for its extreme brutality, so food mentioned above could all be luxuriant in some battles, like the Siege of Leningrad and Battle of Stalingrad.\nRye bread looks like this was already incredibly good in Leningrad\nFor more detail of the worst situation of food supply in Leningrad, watch this video:\nThe Great Patriotic War. Leningrad. Episode 5. StarMedia. Docudrama. English Subtitles (15:57\u201316:47)\nA soldier fought for Leningrad could only received less than 300 grams of bread per day, which the bread was made of burnt flour, food cellulose (sawdust) from wood processing and banknotes making, stale bran and a tiny proportion of fresh flour.\nDuring the Battle of Stalingrad, the supply line was exposed to German artillery and Stuka\u2019s bombardment, making the supply to Stalingrad very difficult. Small planes were counted on for dropping supply at nights, food was surely inadequate for all Soviet troops. A commissar had no difference on the amount of food received either, some of them traded their watches and luxuries for a long smoked sausage or a loaf of rye bread (equals a 10-day ration for several soldiers). Still, these brave men managed to defeat the 6th Army with extreme hunger and tiredness.\nIn other regions, Soviet soldiers who did not want to wait for supply would attack the German supply convoy and rob the German rations to cure hungers. Of course, it was never a sustainable way to feed the entire Soviet Army. Since October 1941, Lend-Lease Program began the US deliveries to the Soviet Union, including food. Finally, Stalin had adequate food to feed his massive army. (Actually, the amount of food sent from the US wasn't enough until early 1943 as the US had to figure out ways to minimize the destruction against the Arctic convoy by Germans, the establishment of another supply route, as well as the analysis on the strategic value of supply to USSR.)\nCanned food, chocolate bars and boxes with beverage powders not only filled soldiers\u2019 stomachs, but also morale for combat.\nC rations were also on the list\nBut perhaps the most famous food for the Soviets was this:\nSPAM!!!!!!!!! (luncheon meat)\nNikita Khrushchev declared: \"Without Spam we wouldn't have been able to feed our army.\" in his memoir. Just like the corned beef, Soviet soldiers loved to put it between two slices of bread to turn it into a sandwich.\nApart from black tea, coffee and cocoa powder that provided energy and acted as morale boosters, there was one more thing that every soldier loved to see and wanted it so bad that they would not hesitate to put their cigarettes aside for drinking just a sip of it, that is\u2026\u2026.\nVodka!!!!!! (I know it doesn't look appealing but picture of a vodka bottle from that era is hard to find\u2026)\nThe old brand of Russian vodka\u2026..I just can\u2019t find one with original brand name (\u0421\u0442\u043e\u043b\u044c\u043d\u0430\u044f) on it.\nTo fight alcoholism that might decrease combat effectiveness, soldiers were not given vodka for daily ration. Soldiers could only have a tiny shot (100 grams, for a Russian tough guy of course) before the battles or celebration of victory. Later, officers found that vodka was most useful on boosting troops\u2019 morale and they began to introduce vodka (100 grams) for better combat effectiveness. In the Battle of Stalingrad, bottles of vodka were packed into boxes with parachutes for light airplanes to carry for dropping onto the Soviet troops so that they could keep on fighting for more vodka and refuse to surrender, having great effect on turning low-morale troops into war heroes.\nLast but not least, soldiers needed their food cooked by cooks. Their contribution for defeating the Nazis should never be forgotten just like the heroes who picked up their rifles and put rains of leads to crush the enemies. Just like what Napoleon said: \u201can army marched on its stomach\u201d. Those army chefs showed their creativity on making dishes when the food supply ran low, they still managed to make food appealing, yummy and nutritious with the only ingredients that they could get. They might make mistakes from time to time, but we can\u2019t deny that those cooks really did their jobs for feeding the glorious Red Army during the Great Patriotic War.\nI think this is it for the answer.", "Anything they could find. Stalin\u2019s \u2018burnt/scorched earth\u2019 policy worked not only against the German army but the Soviet army as well. There was no food for Anyone on Either side!", "Giancarlo,\nFood, same as any other army. Lol. I would imagine fish borscht which is beet soup and whatever they could scrounge.", "According to the article, \u201cWartime cuisine: What did Soviet soldiers eat during World War II?, Russian Kitchen, May 9, 2018 by Maria Afonina the soldiers ate a variety of food.\nField kitchens provided bread, groats, macaroni, 150g of meat, 100g of fish, sugar ,tea, salt, vegetables(potatoes, cabbage, beets, etc.)\nSoviet submariners and pilots received better rations, eggs, butter, fruit, etc. There was also a ration for cigarettes for most troops. The article mentions \u201crusks\u201d which were a type of biscuit. There was also a \u201cRzhevsky\u201d bread made from potatoes and then cooked with bran.\nThe Americans and other allies provided the Soviets with cornmeal. In addition I read from other sources that they were provided with Spam but I can\u2019t confirm this.", "A large part from the US(12,000,000 tons) delivered by US vehicles by the tens of thousands didn\u2019t hurt.Had the germans kept their August/September 1942 line until a year later mass starvation would have forced a Soviet surrender.", "In addition to basic daily rations they received fresh or condensed milk, cottage cheese, sour cream, eggs, butter and cheese, as well as fruit extract and dried fruit. Submariners also had special additions to their diet: red wine, sauerkraut, salted cucumbers and raw onions", "Recently I met article about food of German and Russian soldiers. To my surprise, quality and volume were almost similar with following difference: Russian food was more energetic and included fat, hot soups, etc. Though Germans had chocolate and biscuits, and consumed a lot of Pervetin (doping) and Shnaps (German low quality vodka) .\nAnother negative side for Germans and allies, was low level of personal hygiene, this was very noticeable in Stalingrad battle. Russians had the banya (kind of sauna) on regular basis: once a week with replacement of complete uniform, while Germans, Italians, Poles, French, Finnish, Romanians and other member of German coalition had it may be once a winter.", "Anything they could. They had ration cards depending on what your rank was determined how much food you got.", "They enjoyed a whole lot of \u201cAmerican Spam\u201d, which was a real treat for them.\n- -\n- - Lend-Lease: How American supplies aided the USSR in its darkest hour - -\nSCIENCE & TECH\n, MARCH 14 2016\nCaption: The 1st Baltic Front tankers having a rest near the Sherman tank, supplied under Lend-Lease by the US. Credit: Sergey Baranov/RIA Novosti\n\u201c\u201d\u201d\u201d This month marks 75 years since the United States launched its Lend-Lease program to supply the Allies with much-needed war materiel for the fight against Hitler.\nDownplayed by the Soviet Union, the program was of vital importance to the USSR\u2019s war effort, as even Marshal Zhukov later admitted.\nOn March 11, 1941, American President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the Lend-Lease bill, which permitted the U.S. to supply its anti-Hitler coalition allies with materiel.\n\u2018And how much sheet steel they gave us!\u2019\n\"Now they say that the allies never helped us, but it can't be denied that the Americans gave us so many goods without which we wouldn't have been able to form our reserves and continue the war,\" Soviet General Georgy Zhukov said after the end of WWII.\n\"We didn\u2019t have explosives, gunpowder. We didn\u2019t have anything to charge our rifle cartridges with. The Americans really saved us with their gunpowder and explosives. And how much sheet steel they gave us! How could we have produced our tanks without American steel? But now they make it seem as if we had an abundance of all that. Without American trucks we wouldn\u2019t have had anything to pull our artillery with.\"\nA loan that became history\nRussian historian: Importance of Lend-Lease cannot be overestimated\nThe history of Lend-Lease began on May 15, 1940 when UK Prime Minister Winston Churchill asked Roosevelt to temporarily give Britain 40-50 old destroyers in exchange for British naval and air bases in the Atlantic Ocean.\nThe Americans remembered a law from 1892 in accordance with which the defense secretary can \"lease army property for a maximum of five years if the country does not need it.\" Based on this law a supply program was developed, which Roosevelt signed into law on March 11, 1941.\nAccording to the program, American materials \"destroyed, lost or used during the war were not subject to payment.\"\nWhat had to be paid for was the property that remained after the war and was used for civilian purposes.\n\u2018The common enemy \u2013 bloodthirsty Hitlerism\u2019\nSoviet leader Joseph Stalin decided to join Lend-Lease soon after Hitler's Germany invaded the USSR in June 1941.\nThe U.S., UK, and Canada supplied the USSR with some $130 billion worth of supplies during WWII. Source: Anatoly Garanin / RIA Novosti\n\"Your decision, Mr. President, to give the Soviet Union an interest-free credit of $1 billion in the form of materiel supplies and raw materials has been accepted by the Soviet government with heartfelt gratitude as urgent aid to the Soviet Union in its enormous and difficult fight against the common enemy \u2013 bloodthirsty Hitlerism,\" Stalin wrote to Roosevelt.\nThe first convoys with American goods were already being sent to the USSR by August 1941.\nShortly afterwards the Germans found out about the convoy routes, and the allies suffered great losses. During the war Nazi submarines and torpedoes sank about 80 cargo ships destined for the USSR.\nMore than 14,000 U.S. airplanes, 8,000 of which came from Alaska, were given to the Soviet Union in the course of the war.\nThe USSR received a total of 44,000 American jeeps, 375,883 cargo trucks, 8,071 tractors, and 12,700 tanks. Additionally, 1,541,590 blankets, 331,066 liters of alcohol, 15,417,000 pairs of army boots, 106,893 tons of cotton, 2,670,000 tons of petroleum products and 4,478,000 tons of food supplies made their way into the Soviet Union.\n\u2018The Russian government wants to hide the fact that it receives help from outside\u2019\nAnd yet, during the war the Soviet government diminished the role of foreign aid. This made U.S. Ambassador to the USSR William Standley indignant.\n75 years ago the U.S. signed a bill to provide its allies with vital goods. Source: RIA Novosti\n\"It seems that the Russian government wants to hide the fact that it receives help from outside.\nObviously it wants to ensure its people that the Red Army is fighting this war alone,\" he said during a press conference in March 1943.\n\"After stormy five-hour telephone talks the Russian censorship allowed Standley's text to be published,\" the BBC's Moscow correspondent Alexander Werth later recalled.\n\"The employees at the press department were angry. Chief censor Kozhemyako was white with rage putting his stamp on the telegram. His mother had died in Leningrad from hunger.\u201d\nMoscow exits list of world\u2019s top 100 most expensive cities\nAfter the end of WW II the U.S. asked countries to pay for the civilian supplies they received (steamboats, trucks, power plants). The U.S. believed that the USSR had to pay $1.3 billion, yet Soviet government officials said they could only pay $170 million.\nObviously, the U.S. did not accept these conditions, which led to talks in 1972 at which the two countries signed an agreement whereby the USSR was obliged to pay the U.S. $722 million by 2001.\nIn the course of the following year the Soviet Union paid $48 million, but due to the American Jackson-Vanik amendment the Soviet Union ceased the payments.\nThe amendment restricted trade with countries that impeded emigration and violated other human rights.\nOne of the reasons for Washington introducing the amendment was the USSR's refusal to let Jews out of the country.\nIn 1990 America and the Soviet Union returned to the talks. It was decided that by 2030 America would receive $674 million. A year later the USSR collapsed.\nBut in 1993 the Russian government announced its succession to the debts and soon paid for all the goods that the USSR had received in accordance with the Lend-Lease bill\u201d\u201d\u201d, Lend-Lease: How American supplies aided the USSR in its darkest hour\n.\nA full version is available in Russian\n.\n(All rights reserved by Rossiyskaya Gazeta).", "Beef. This pandemic is reshaping the way people buy and consume meat. Unable to eat out, many consumers are buying more chicken breasts and eggs to eat at home. No nutrition program should teach that there is a \"yes\" or \"no\" answer when it comes to nutrition, except for \"yes\": we need nutrient dense food and \"no\": chemistry lab projects have no place in our bodies.\nSecond, not all vegetables are created equal. Some vegetables are as starchy as fruits, meaning that per serving, they deliver the same amount of carbohydrate. So if we create a juice or smoothie with fruits and starchy vegetables, we will have made something that exceeds our per-pit-stop nutrition needs for quick energy. You can blend and mix and \u201cpaint\u201d with flavour. Salty, sweet you get the idea.\nFood is like sound too. When you listen to instruments playing separately it sounds like noise but when they play in the right way, it is called harmony and it can be beautiful. Sometimes though you want a little noise though. You want a crashing cymbal or just something a bit more jarring than a melody.\nFood can also be like a mood too. You know how you can be happy or sad. But you can also feel blah. Or really any number of other emotions. There's a whole world of emotion right?\nJust like all of these other things have a simple way to see them they also have more complex ways too. You can't really make neon with your crayons unless you have a neon crayon right? You can't really get the same sound of a drum as you do from banging pots and pans.\nAnd this is what umami is. It's a really crazy intense and different experience compared to the other things you might be more used to. There's a big difference between Baby Shark and Mozart's Marriage of Figaro. There's a huge difference between a paint by number and the ceiling of the Sistine chapel.\nUmami is a lot like those key things that make them different. It might seem like magic but it isn't. It's just a type of science you need to feel and taste and experience. It's what happens when food puts a spell on you.\nNow, go out there and enjoy the magic of the world!", "Umami is the flavor of meat. Think about tender, juicy pot roast, grilled steak. The aroma of roasted meat, the flavor of flat-top cooked hamburger.", "Its a salty, meaty flavour. Its the taste of seafood. The taste of clam broth from a bowl of clams, or mussles. Its a delicious taste. Picture the flavour of parmesran cheese, tomato, doritos, or even mushrooms. Umami is savoury and the taste if it makes you want another bite or spoonful of what youre eating. Have you ever used maggie seasoning, bovril boillion, vegmite, marmite, or msg?. Do you remember the beefy taste of consumme, a bouillion cube, or the lovely flavour of anchovies?. Miso, dashi, soy sauce, many fermented foods have umami. Spam, salami, basically its a salty savoury deliciousness that we all love!!!", "In Japanese, it means \u201cthe flavour of tastiness\u201d. In the west, it\u2019s sometimes called \u201csavoury\u201d.\nImagine you\u2019re eating a piece of regular cheddar cheese (the natural crumbly stuff, not the processed plastic stuff that comes in slices or individually wrapped cubes). It\u2019s a little sweet, but not sweet. It\u2019s salty, but not salty. It\u2019s a little sour, but not really sour. It\u2019s sharp like a lemon, except it isn\u2019t. That doesn\u2019t make any sense, but you\u2019ve eaten cheese\u2014you know what I mean. That is umami.", "The first answer takes certain scientific liberties in that I am describing it to a 5 year old.\nAnswer 1: Umami is a taste like sweet, sour, bitter and salty. But if sweet is yellow and sour is green, then umami would be white or black. It is a taste that enhances or changes other tastes. It is like drawing yellow with a black background or brown on a white background. The yellow and brown \u2018pops\u2019. Certain foods have more umami, such as mushrooms, and these can be used to make foods \u2018pop\u2019.\nAnswer 2: There has been a lot of debate about umami. But scientists have now established that there are separate receptors in the tongue that detect umami. By that definition it is a separate taste. Meaning and unlike some other tastes like \u2018smokey\u2019 which is a result of 3 receptors firing to give you a combined \u2018flavor\u2019, umami is a stand-alone taste like sweet, sour, bitter and salt. Umami is very subtle and the best description is probably one of earthy savoriness. Another characteristic of umami is that it has a long lasting after taste. The combination of characteristics means that umami combines well with other tastes almost like a binder, making sweet, sweeter and mellows bitter by adding depth."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Brock Sheldon", "view_list": [20, 3, 13, 17, 101]}, "643": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What do you need for a kitchen checklist?", "topic_list": ["Checklists", "Kitchen Design", "Kitchen Utensils and Accessories", "Kitchens", "Flooring", "Home Improvement", "Cooking", "Food", "Survey Question"], "no_of_view": "327", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Jeet Rathi", "view_list": []}, "94": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is the long term effect of food mold? Almonds are tree nuts rather seeds and hence this cover or peel is provided to protect it from moisture and sunlight\nAlmonds are a great healthy addition to any diet. They contain monounsaturated fats, which are great for all kinds\nof things\n.\nIt is, however, essential that you soak almonds for at least 8 hours before eating them. See this chart of soaking times\nfor all kinds of nuts and beans.\nNuts like almonds are naturally coated with enzyme inhibitors, which prevent the almonds sprouting and turning into almond trees until they get really wet. Usually it's the thickness (or lack thereof) that causes it to fall off during cooking.\nWhen breading fish, you should always start by coating it with flour. Then beaten whole eggs, then breadcrumbs. Make sure you press the breadcrumbs into the fish and if you want it extra crispy, repeat the egg and breadcrumbs steps.", "First, I usually add about a tablespoon of cornstarch in the breading mix to help create a breading that is stickier. Then, like Davis Appleton notes, I don't beat them up. Sometimes I use a slurry that I brush on one side, drop them into a fry pan, and brush on the opposite side. Once the first side is browned, I carefully turn them over and brown the other side. That provides a nice crust that isn\u2019t too thick or easily removed. My slurry is 1 tablespoon of butter, one tablespoon of flour, and one teaspoon of cornstarch. Multiply by how many ever units you need to cover your item you are cooking. Works wonderfully for chicken cutlets, too. That is one of the rare times I will offer any kind of recipe, and I didn\u2019t create it. But it works well if you have trouble with your breading falling off. Corn starch works well as a helper. Also, double bread by dredging in your flour mix first, then in your liquid, then the flour mix again. That makes a nice breading mix that tend to stick well if deep frying or pan frying.", "Don\u2019t plop them in the oil. Carefully lower them in the fry basket, then slowly raise it when done. This is because, the surface and skin of the fish on death does not remain sterile. It gets invaded by the external bacteria, and the enteric bacteria and intestinal enzymes start decomposing the flesh immediately after the rigor mortis ends. Thus any fresh fish, if it is to be preserved has to be chilled below 0 degree centigrade or at least kept in crushed ice mixed with salt.\nBest way to preserve the fresh fish is to wash it first with freshwater if the fish is a marine one, and with salt water if the fish is a freshwater fish. Then, cut open its belly, wash the body cavity as above, remove the entrails completely and smear the body cavity and the outer body surface with salt and turmeric. Keep this fish in the freezer. It will remain fresh for at least 8 to 10 days.\nThe dehydration (total) will also preserve the fish for consumption. This can be done by sun drying with or without salt. Best way to do this, is by hanging in the sun.", "You never use airtight container to preserve fish, as it\u2019s a sure way to get botulism. Botulism bacterium is an anaerobc one, and thrives in the airless conditions. Fish is usually preserved by salting it in brine (the common barrel-salted herring, for example), but the barrels are mever fully airtight, and the salting solution often contains nitrates to contain the botulism, or by drying it \u2014 with or without salting it before. Air-dried fish is always shipped well-ventilated, to prevent wetting and resulting spoilage. You can only airtight or nitrogen-store the completely dried (as in <5% moisture) and stabilized fish, which has no remaining deep-tissue moisture that can raise to the surface."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Rajeev Sharma", "view_list": [100, 326]}, "113": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What happens if you consume too much microplastics?", "topic_list": ["Microplastics", "Plastic", "Eating", "Human Body", "Science", "Hypothetical Scenarios", "Food", "Medicine and Healthcare"], "no_of_view": "285", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Shane Davis", "view_list": []}, "833": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Romeo DiBattista Jr.", "Reva Pearlston"], "question_title": "What happens if you eat cheese that smells bad?", "topic_list": ["Cheese", "Smell and Smells", "Eating", "Food"], "no_of_view": "425", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["It depends.
