If so, when should I toss it/them out?", "topic_list": ["Black Pepper", "Peppers", "Spices", "Sodium Chloride", "Expiration Dates and Product Expiration", "Food Safety", "Salt", "Cooking", "Health", "Food"], "no_of_view": "932", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 1, 1, 0, 2, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Salt never \u201cexpires\u201d as it is a mineral. Melange pepper corns - well I have never had a problem as I buy them in a very large container and have had the same canister for over 3 years and they still states rich", "Salt is a rock. It doesn't expire and it doesn't lose flavour. Pepper is dried seeds. Pepper will lose flavour over time. If the smell is getting faint, it's too old and needs to be tossed. Peppercorns keep better than ground pepper. That's why fresh ground pepper smells and tastes so good.", "As others have said, salt is a mineral. It will last forever (a lot of salt comes out of mines, just like other minerals). Pepper comes from a plant. As others have said, it will start to lose some of its natural flavor and aroma after time. Throw it out when it no longer smells the way you want your pepper to smell. It will still be safe to use, though.\nBut let\u2019s talk about the meaning of \u201cexpired.\u201d \u201cExpired\u201d actually has no meaning when it comes to food products. That\u2019s why you don\u2019t actually see the word \u201cexpired\u201d very often. You are more likely to see \u201cuse by\u201d or \u201cbest by.\u201d\nSo food doesn\u2019t \u201cexpire,\u201d and it certainly doesn\u2019t expire on a certain date. Do you think that can of corn on your shelf was okay for 364 days and became toxic on the 365th?\n\u201cUse\u201d or \u201cBest by\u201d dates (which are required by the government, regardless of whether the item is really perishable) are generally the producer\u2019s conservative estimate of when the item will still have retained its quality. That can of corn will still be pretty much the same as the day it was canned, and not mushy and discolored. That box of crackers won\u2019t be stale.\nBut let me say this loudly: those dates have very little to do with whether the food is SAFE to eat. That depends completely on whether the food was prepared properly (i.e. not contaminated during the production process) and stored properly. If you leave your milk on the counter for a week, it\u2019s going to be bad regardless of the date on the package. If the distributor didn\u2019t refrigerate it properly, it could be bad before the date. If you contaminate something by putting a dirty utensil in it (or cutting it on a dirty cutting board) and then put it back in the refrigerator, it may be bad before the \u201cexpiration\u201d date. On the other hand, food that is stored properly \u2014 properly sealed and refrigerated \u2014 can be safe to eat for much longer than the \u201cexpiration\u201d date. Anything that is \u201cshelf stable\u201d won\u2019t \u201cspoil\u201d \u2014 it will just decline in quality over time (that box of crackers could be stale, but it\u2019s not unsafe). People throw out tons of perfectly good food every year because they are needlessly worried about \u201cexpiration\u201d dates.\nFinally, \u201cbad\u201d can mean different things. It can mean \u201cthis no longer tastes good\u201d for a product that is still safe to consume. It can mean \u201cthis has been in the fridge too long and it doesn\u2019t smell good\u201d \u2014 that might or might not make you sick if you ate it. Generally speaking, if it doesn\u2019t smell good, don\u2019t eat it (why would you want to, anyway?). But there is another kind of bad: bad because it contains pathogens, like salmonella or listeria. Those, unfortunately, you cannot smell, and they have very little to do with how the food was stored and mostly to do with the fact that it was contaminated in the production process. That chicken in your fridge that smells bad doesn\u2019t have salmonella just from being there a long time. It\u2019s unlikely it smells bad because it has salmonella, but if it does have salmonella, it\u2019s because it had salmonella when you bought it. I once got listeria from something I had bought at the store and eaten the same day \u2014 it was already \u201cbad\u201d when I bought it.", "Not in my opinion.", "Your salt is already a few million years old when you purchase it, so no.\nPepper, if already ground, begins to lose potency and aroma immediately \u2013 which is why \u201cwould you like some freshly-ground pepper on your salad?\u201d is a thing.\nWhole peppercorns are probably best if no more than a year old, but if kept in a vacuum-sealed container, can last for years.", "I have never checked the label on salt if there is an expiry date. As long as it is kept dry and in your cupboard my guess is that you will use it up before it ever expires. On the other hand, black and white pepper whether pre-ground or whole corns will lose flavor over time. I usually purchase pepper corns to grind them myself. For me I will use up a large container (19.4 ounces) within 7 months. But if you purchased ground pepper in a small container, it will lose taste and It\u2019s peppery kick within 3\u20136. There is nothing as bad as tasteless pepper.", "Dont think so?", "well salt can re solidify, but is easy enough to stop, and pepper i assume would lose a bit of potency over time, but not go \u2018off\u2019"], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Sarah Nguyen", "view_list": [23, 148, 61, 5, 105, 39, 4, 3]}, "485": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Where can you buy tea that has theacrine in it?", "topic_list": ["Herbal Teas (tisane)", "Stimulants", "Nootropics", "Healthy Beverages", "Green Tea", "Tea", "Beverages", "Shopping", "Healthy Eating", "Food"], "no_of_view": "489", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Christian Balder D'Amico", "view_list": []}, "836": {"no_of_follower": 9, "respond_collected": 11, "name_list": ["Prashant Kasumiya", "Vaishnava Seva Dasa", "Laal Musaddi", "Satwant Singh", "Anonymous", "Shri Datta Swami", "Ramkumar Balaraman", "Gary Regnon", "Gerald Zuckier", "K. Krishnamurti", "Erin Paige Law"], "question_title": "Why do many Indians who are vegetarian eat eggs, but not chicken or any other non vegetarian food?", "topic_list": ["Vegetarians", "Vegetarian Food", "Eggs (food)", "Vegetarianism", "Food"], "no_of_view": "7,496", "create_time": "Feb 19, 2013", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 8, 2, 0, 0, 0, 1, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["Depends on individually. But in scientific way these word are incorrect. Scientific word is herbivores, carnivore. You can find these words in our history millions years ago. If you are interested in healthy lifestyle you can follow me on Instagram - prashantkasumiya", "Because our ignorance they feel eggs are veg\nOn the spiritual path, there are several reasons why a person is recommended to be vegetarian. One primary reason is that we need to see the spiritual nature within all living beings, and that includes the animals and other creatures as well. Universal brotherhood means nonviolence to both humans and animals. It consists of understanding that animals also have souls. They are alive, conscious, and feel pain. And these are the indications of the presence of consciousness, which is the symptom of the soul. Even the Bible (Genesis 1.21; 1.24; 1.30; 2.7; and in many other places) refers to both animals and people as nefesh chayah, living souls. Those who eat meat, however, because of their desires to eat animals or see them as a source of food for one\u2019s stomach, are not so easily able to understand the spiritual nature of all beings. After all, if you know that all living entities are spiritual in essence, and that all living beings that are conscious show the symptoms of the soul within, then how can you kill them unnecessarily? Any living creature is also the same as we are in the respect that it is also a child of the same father, a part of the same Supreme Being. Thus, the killing of animals shows a great lack in spiritual awareness.\nMany portions of the Vedic literature describe how the Supreme Being is the maintainer of innumerable living entities, humans as well as the animals, and is alive in the heart of every living being. Only those with spiritual consciousness can see the same Supreme Being in His expansion as Supersoul within every creature. To be kind and spiritual toward humans and be a killer or enemy toward animals is not a balanced philosophy, and exhibits one\u2019s spiritual ignorance.\nThe next reason for being vegetarian is to consider the amount of fear and suffering that animals experience in the slaughter industry. There are countless stories of how in fear cows cry, scream, and sometimes fall down dead while inside or even before they are taken into the slaughter house. Or how the veins of dead pigs are so big that it shows they have practically exploded from the fear the pig felt and the adrenalin that was produced while it was being led to slaughter. This certainly causes an immense amount of violence to permeate the atmosphere, which goes out and falls back on us in some form. Furthermore, the adrenalin and fear in the animal also produces toxins which then permeate the body of these animals, which meat-eaters ingest. People who consume such things cannot help but be effected by it. It causes tensions within them individually, which then spreads in their relations with others.\nThe ancient Vedic text of the Manu-samhita (5.45-8) says, \u201cHe who injures innoxious beings from a wish to give himself pleasure never finds happiness, neither living nor dead. He who does not seek to cause the suffering of bonds and death to living creatures, but desires the good of all beings, obtains endless bliss. . . Meat can never be obtained without injury to living creatures, and injury to sentient beings is detrimental to the attainment of heavenly bliss; let him therefore shun the use of meat.\u201d\nThe Bible (Romans 14.21) also says, \u201cIt is neither good to eat flesh, nor to drink wine.\u201d Another biblical commandment (Exodus 23.5) instructs us to help animals in pain, even if they belong to an enemy.\nThe Buddhist scripture (Sutta-Nipata 393) also advises: \u201cLet him not destroy or cause to be destroyed any life at all, or sanction the acts of those who do so. Let him refrain from even hurting any creature, both those that are strong and those that tremble in the world.\u201d It is also said in the Buddhist scripture, the Mahaparinirvana Sutra, \u201cThe eating of meat extinguishes the seed of great compassion.\u201d\nFor Jews, the Talmud (Avodah Zorah 18B) forbids the association with hunters, not to mention engaging in hunting.\nIn the New Testament Jesus preferred mercy over sacrifice (Matthew 9.13; 12.7) and was opposed to the buying and selling of animals for sacrifice (Matthew 21.12-14; Mark 11.15; John 2.14-15). One of the missions of Jesus was to do away with animal sacrifice and cruelty to animals (Hebrews 10.5-10).\nWe especially find in Isaiah where Jesus scorns the slaughter and bloodshed of humans and animals. He declares (1.15) that God does not hear the prayers of animal killers: \u201cBut your iniquities have separated you and your God. And your sins have hid His face from you, so that He does not hear. For your hands are stained with blood. . . Their feet run to evil and they hasten to shed innocent blood. . . they know not the ways of peace.\u201d Isaiah also laments that he saw, \u201cJoy and merrymaking, slaughtering of cattle and killing of sheep, eating of meat and drinking of wine, as you thought, \u2018let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.\u2019\u201d (22.13)\nIt is also established in the Bible (Isaiah 66.3), \u201cHe that killeth an ox is as if he slew a man.\u201d In this regard St. Basil (320-379 A.D.) taught, \u201cThe steam of meat darkens the light of the spirit. One can hardly have virtue if one enjoys meat meals and feasts.\u201d\nThus, we should find alternatives to killing animals to satisfy our appetites, especially when there are plenty of other healthy foods available. Otherwise, there must be reactions to such violence. We cannot expect peace in the world if we go on unnecessarily killing so many millions of animals for meat consumption or through abuse.\nThe third factor for being vegetarian is karma. As Newton's third law of motion states, for every action there must be an equal and opposite reaction. On the universal scale this is called the law of karma, meaning what goes around comes around. This affects every individual, as well as communities and countries. As the nation sows, so shall it reap. This is something we should take very seriously, especially in our attempt to bring peace, harmony, and unity into the world. If so much violence is produced by the killing of animals, where do you think the reactions to this violence goes? It comes back to us in so many ways, such as the form of neighborhood and community crime, and on up to world wars. Violence breeds violence. Therefore, this will continue unless we know how to change.\nIsaac Bashevis Singer, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature, asked, \u201cHow can we pray to God for mercy if we ourselves have no mercy? How can we speak of rights and justice if we take an innocent creature and shed its blood?\u201d He went on to say, \u201cI personally believe that as long as human beings will go shedding the blood of animals, there will never be any peace.\u201d\nIn conclusion, we can mention the March 10, 1966 issue of L\u2019Osservatore della Domenica, the Vatican weekly newspaper, in which Msgr. Ferdinando Lambruschini wrote: \u201cMan\u2019s conduct with regard to animals should be regulated by right reason, which prohibits the infliction of purposeless pain and suffering on them. To ill treat them, and make them suffer without reason, is an act of deplorable cruelty to be condemned from a Christian point of view. To make them suffer for one\u2019s own pleasure is an exhibition of sadism which every moralist must denounce.\u201d Eating animals for the pleasure of one\u2019s tongue when there are plenty of other foods available certainly fits into this form of sadism. It stands to reason that this is counterproductive to any peace and unity or spiritual progress we wish to make. It is one of the things we need to consider seriously if we want to improve ourselves or the world. So here are a few reasons why a genuinely spiritual person will choose to be vegetarian.", "Q: Why do many Indians who are vegetarian eat eggs, but not chicken or any other non vegetarian food?\nNo, egg is not a vegetarian product. Egg is a non-vegetarian produce. Compare with the word \u201cvegetation\u201d.\nVegetarians lives on the vegetation|flora [cooked] produce.\nNon-vegetarians live on the vegetation|flora as well as eggs|meats|fauna [cooked] produce.\nEgg should not be treated as a vegetarian food.\nMammalian milk is a mammalian produce.\nSome % of vegetarians might after eating eggs, drinking milk, and [cooked] food preparation from milk derivatives such as [clarified] butter, curd, cream, puneer, sri-khand, consider (may|do) themselves as vegetarians.\nIt is their convenience, clarification and classification.", "India is a country where vegetarian food was available because of its climate and other factors.\nOn the other hand most regions which are more cold or deserts have less vegetation.\nIt is the matter of availability that matters more.\nCustoms and traditions also responsible for the same.\nIt is said that in India non vegetarian food was eaten by even the religious Hindu people.\nIt is also said whether it is true or not that Buddhism was spreading in India because of its non violent principles. And to counter it Hindu leadership adopted vegetarianism more rigidly.\nWe Indians according to our customs and traditions don't take any time while killing snakes and rats. And in the matter of food vegetarianism stands in front of us.\nIn case of eggs because there is no killing of any animals so justification for eating of eggs is not much difficult.", "Most of the vegetarian Indians I know don't eat eggs, poultry, fish or other meat. For many, it is based on religious/spiritual principles of non-violence (i.e. not killing a living being). For others it is habit (what they were brought up with), underlined by these principles. This is more than sadism because a sadist enjoys by harming another person and he has no alternative person there for such enjoyment. If you analyze this subject through your sharp intelligence, you will find that the vegetarian food is far better than non-vegetarian food as per the medical science.\n\nThe proteins extracted by you from the plants in your vegetarian food are primary and are very good for health. Think a while that you are in its position and then discuss the subject. There is no sin in eating a naturally dead animal and a sect of Hindus called as Kapalikas do this and are not found fault for this. The mind is represented by the nervous system, which is not present in the plants. The mind may be in very very primitive stage in plants as per the research of Mr. Bose. The ancient Indian sages avoided even plucking the leaves and fruits.\n\nThey ate leaves and fruits when they have fallen from the plants (Swayam Viseerna Dhruva Patra Vruttita). They avoided this trace of sin also. In plucking the leaf and killing an animal, the sin is qualitatively equal, but there is a lot of quantitative difference. One percent sin and hundred percent sin cannot be equated. Your argument concludes that if one does one percent sin, why not hundred percent sin be done? This equates to your statement that if one plucks a leaf why not we kill an animal.\n\nAre you pained equally if I steal one rupee(1 CENT) or one lakh rupees (1 MILLION $) from your pocket. Almost all of the best crop-growing land was given to absentee landlord supporters of Cromwell\u2019s Protectorate, \u2026some of them Irish, and most not. That left for the Irish, themselves, a lot of sandy and poor-grade soils that would grow little wheat or barley per acre.\nBut potatoes had been recently introduced from South America, and their yield of calories per acre on those poor soils was much higher than any other crop that the Irish were at all used to eating. So, they began planting more potatoes, and famine went way, and the Irish population started growing again. One variant of the hundreds of variants of potatoes did better than any other in these poor soils, and was soon used by poor Irish throughout the island.\nThat continued till the 19th Century, when any land for any crop was starting to become short, because of population growth. Then a load of potatoes arrived in Antwerp from the US, and some of those were shipped on to Ireland. They contained the water mold, Phytophora Infestans. It loved potatoes as much as the Irish, or more. With the mold spreading from Antwerp, 250,000 died of famine on the continent, while a million died in Ireland, and another million emigrated."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Thao Dao", "view_list": [123]}, "712": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Meg Osterby", "Laurence Howey"], "question_title": "Do pickles need to be canned?", "topic_list": ["Pickling", "Canned Foods", "Pickles", "Food"], "no_of_view": "364", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["No. You can make refrigerateor pickles. For the vast majority of people, everything, technically, ends up being store-bought: flour, sugar, yeast, cinnamon, and so on. If you happen to have some kind of plantation in Mexico or Vietnam or some place like that, I suppose you could grow cinnamon trees, sugar cane, wheat, and all the other necessary ingredients, but that\u2019s not really an option for nearly everybody.\nThat said, it\u2019s very easy to make cinnamon rolls with very basic ingredients, and there are any number of recipes for them out there: start by making a relatively soft and possibly slightly sweet yeast dough, roll it out, smear with butter, sprinkle with a cinnamon-sugar mixture, roll up, cut into slices (showing the spiral cross section), put into a pan, and bake. Everything you need is something you\u2019d use for many other recipes, so there\u2019s no specific cinnamon roll sub-assembly you\u2019d need to buy specifically for them and only them."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Channel Chitwood", "view_list": [114]}, "539": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Jennifer Abramson", "Stuart James", "Calvin Gibson", "Robert Walker"], "question_title": "What kind of bacon shrivels up the least?", "topic_list": ["Bacon", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "1,194", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 1], "ans_list": ["It doesn't shrivel much when wrapped around something.", "Thicker bacon tends to curl less than thin sliced, and baking your bacon instead of frying will help as well. Bacon which has more meat and less fat will shrivel less, however, but IMO, the thicker, the longer and the wider the bacon is cut, the less it will shrivel."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Diane Sanders", "view_list": [4, 5, 2, 51]}, "85": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Sf Anniston"], "question_title": "Which meat is the most expensive?", "topic_list": ["Meat", "Pricing", "Food"], "no_of_view": "284", "create_time": "Apr 30, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["This is wagyu beef, one of the most expensive meats in the world. Produced in Japan and prized for its rich marbling and buttery taste, high-grade wagyu can cost up to $200 per pound, and the cows themselves can sell for as much as $30,000. But what is it that makes the meat so expensive?\nThe term wagyu literally translates to Japanese cow. And it generally refers to four main breeds. These cows were bred for physical endurance, giving them more intramuscular fat cells. The fat is distributed more evenly throughout their muscle, which is why wagyu beef looks pink and tastes so tender. And the Japanese government tightly regulates wagyu production to protect the value and quality of the meat.\nWagyu is graded on two main factors: how much meat can be yielded and the quality of the marbled fat. Only A3 to A5 wagyu is certified for sale in Japan. And the higher the grade, the higher the price. Wagyu beef has gained almost legendary status, and there are many myths about wagyu farms and the way the animals are treated, from getting daily massages to being fed beer. But these often aren't true.\nThe cows are raised very differently in each region and by different farmers, but they're often raised by a breeder until they're about 10 months old and then sold at auction to a fattening farmer. By the time the calves are sold at auction, they can already fetch 40 times the price of US cattle. The fattening farm will keep the animals in small pens and feed them a mixture of fiber and high-energy concentrate made from rice, wheat, and hay. They're often fed this three times a day for almost two years, until the animals are almost 50% fat. Only the pregnant cows and breeding cattle are allowed to graze on pasture.\nThe length of the fattening process and the import prices of the huge amount of concentrated feed increases the cost of the beef, and over this fattening period, each cow will eat 5 tons of feed. If and when a cow goes to auction, it can sell for as much as $30,000.\nComparatively, black Angus cattle, which are considered the cream of the crop in countries like the United States and Australia, typically don't sell for more than $3,000. And depending on the kind, the wagyu can fetch close to $200 per pound.\nHigh marbling is the common goal, but the approach varies by farm and area. While there are more than 300 varieties of wagyu available, the most notable cuts come from 10 regions. One of the most expensive cuts is Matsusaka wagyu from Mie Prefecture, made exclusively from virgin female cows and highly prized for its tenderness. In 2002, one Matsusaka cow sold for 50 million yen, or roughly $400,000. However, the best-known cut of wagyu is Kobe beef, which comes from the city of Kobe in Hyogo Prefecture and is made exclusively from steers, or castrated bulls.\nAlthough Kobe is commonly seen on US restaurant menus, customers should be wary of items like Kobe burgers, as authentic Kobe beef is too tender to be formed into a patty. Several US restaurants are actually serving hybrid \"wangus\" beef from domestically raised wagyu and Angus cows.\nThe highest-ranking wagyu is A5 Miyazaki, a two-time winner of the \"Wagyu Olympics.\" A5 Miyazaki will cost you $100 or more per pound. At SakaMai in New York City, it's the wagyu of choice. The restaurant is best known for serving it in an $85 katsu sando, a popular Japanese-style sandwich.\nKen: On a busy night, we probably serve about 25 of them at $85 a pop. Because wagyu is so difficult to find in the US, yes, we do have a number of customers coming to us just to try the wagyu. Sometimes a two-top will come and just order the sando by itself. There are a lot of tariffs and quotas on Japanese beef imports, and it's actually not allowed to import live cattle. So it is very difficult to source wagyu."], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020"], "question_author": "Vita Lea", "view_list": [15]}, "446": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 7, "name_list": ["Lewis Dynan", "Lonnie Moore", "Aaron Hefferin", "Michael Georgiades", "Ben Robinson", "Jan Gillard", "Mark Roberts"], "question_title": "What if I only have an oven that goes as up as 250\u00b0C but my recipe needs 350\u00b0? :/ can it still cook it? Do I need to wait longer or what? Even most industrial ovens (at least, the ones I know of) have a limit of 250\u00b0C. The only ovens that might go higher than 250\u00b0C would be industrial pizza ovens.", "In all likelihood, you're dealing with two different temperature scales. They can also be pinkish, purple or black - black being the ripest and milder flavoured. Many olives that are sold for snacking or for including in salads will have been treated in some way, the most common being brining. This often changes the colours of the olives and can help in softening green olives. I may use a cabinet smoker or my grill. When I have a cookout, several people are involved. I may or may not fire up the grill. I have made Low County Boil for 25 people using a turkey fryer, and we called it a cookout. We didn\u2019t call it a barbecue. I cook for one or two on my barbecue grill and we have barbecue for lunch or dinner. My late wife and I were once contracted to stay for a 3-day weekend at a location where people rode 4-wheelers all day and came back in the evenings. We had no cooking facilities except a fire, a two burner propane stove, a couple of butane burners, and two tailgater grills. But there were a dozen people in the group and we had a cookout twice a day. It was challenging but a lot of fun. One evening we had 3 additional guests as I had cooked several extra steaks and they were stunned at the quality and taste of the food. We weren\u2019t barbecuing, but we were definitely cooking out. I even did some slow cooked ribs the first full day by cooking them on a homemade rack next to a hardwood fire all day, and the second half involved mopping them in homemade barbecue sauce front and back for about 3 hours. Were we eating barbecue? Yes. Were we cooking out? Of course. I don\u2019t know where you come from but having barbecue generally translates to making food on a grill or in a smoker. Having a cookout involves several people coming together, eating outdoors, usually having alcoholic beverages, and having a good time. Thank you so much!)", "topic_list": ["Mathematics Word Problems", "Restaurants", "Costs", "Problem Solving", "Mathematics", "Food"], "no_of_view": "3,582", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 2], "ans_list": ["I will presume this is just supposed to be a simple math problem.\nYou need to figure out how much you make per meal sold (hint subtraction)\nThen you need to figure out how many times you would have to make that to be grater than or equal to the startup cost (hint division).", "The teacher who gave you this homework problem obviously has no ideas of the costs involved in running a restaurant.\nOn average, in the USA, your food expenses can run no more than about 1/3 of the meal sales price, your labor about 1/3 of the sales price, and everything else (rent, utilities, taxes, and profit) come out of the remaining 1/3 of the sales price.\nThe ratios can vary\u2026 for example, rents would be higher in a high traffic, high cost location.", "It sounds like you are trying to get somebody on Quora to answer a homework problem. Do it yourself and learn!", "It doesn't work like that buddy\nLet me try and simplify it for you\nStart up cost has nothing to do with break even however if your question is about \u201cpayback period\u201d being the \u201cbreak even\u201d then its a different thing\nBreak even sales = fixed cost / contribution\nContribution = 100 percent - variable cost\nFixed costs = rent + salaries + fixed recurring Costs like annual maintenance contracts + telephone rental etc etc\nVariable cost = food cost as a percentage + credit card charges + direct labour if any + commissions to aggregators\nPretty easy to find out but let me give you an imaginary situation\nIf 15 dollars is the selling price and 50 percent is the food cost (7 dollars)\nAssuming 1000 dollars is your fixed cost then break even point will be at\nBep = 1000/ 50 percent = 2000 dollars\n2000 dollars divided by 15 dollars (selling price) is your break even meals which is 133 meals.\nHope I have been able to explain well.\nFollow my blog at Blog | Get Inspired Today", "24875 meals\nProfit per meal is 15\u20137= 8$\nFor breakeven 199000/8= 24875 meals", "15 - 7 =8 Profit on Each Meal\n199,000/8= 24,875\u2014-# of meals needing to be sold to pay for startup costs\nAlot of other variables unaccounted for\u2014-also \u201cbreakeven\u201d definition is not clear", "Never.\nSelling a $7 meal for $15 will never cover the overhead and labor, taxes, fees, etc.\nNeeds to be in the $21 range to sell. and make a profit."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Emma Kate", "view_list": [12, 58, 3, 115, 5, 5, 53]}, "468": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Francine Granville", "Sharla Hulsey", "Beth Goldowitz", "Lucille Yuen", "Ronald Hokanson", "Celia Milton"], "question_title": "What are some creative yet cheap recipes for a person on a low income?", "topic_list": ["Income", "Recipes", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "821", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [1, 3, 4, 2, 1, 4], "ans_list": ["Homemade soups are cheap and easy to make. Chicken wings and drumsticks\nare cheap and can be turned into tasty meals. Spanish omelet and Frittatas\nare cheap and make a nourishing meal, likewise homemade pizza.\nVegetarian pastas dishes are another option. It just takes some thought and\ncreativity.", "Polenta (aka cornmeal mush for us folks who grew up southern): 4 parts water to 1 part corn meal. If using regular, finer ground corn meal, mix it with 1/4 of your water while you get the rest boiling. Add a fan of salt when you pour the corn meal into the boiling water. Turn heat down to medium-low, and cook, stirring, for 10 minutes or so, till it gets really thick. You can eat it not with butter and syrup, like grits; or turn it out into a greased pan, allow to cool, and then sluce. At that point you can reheat it by frying in a bit of butter or bacon grease, and top with tomato sauce and cheese. Once when I was really broke, I made a pan of lentils, and I would fry slices of polenta in a bit of olive oil, then eat it topped with lentils.\nI would recommend, if you can, that you pick up a couple cookbooks: Good and Cheap by Leanne Brown and the Mennonite Central Committee's old More-with-Less Cookbook. Both are invaluable for a budget-conscious kitchen.\nWhen something is on sale, get a bunch of it and freeze in smaller quantities. I like to buy 10 pounds of ground beef when it's cheap, and cook up some for sloppy Joes or tacos or spaghetti sauce, then make meatballs and loaves with the rest. You'll end up with the start of a bunch of meals in your freezer ready to go. Whole pork loins are often on sale, and you can cut chops and roasts from them to freeze for another day. Pork shoulder (butt) is often even cheaper, and after a long, slow simmer it makes good pulled pork or, seasoned right, carnitas.\nLearn to make your own biscuits, corn bread, noodles, and even yeast or sourdough bread.\nLook into ethnic recipes. Many of them originate from poor places.\nUse spices and herbs. My local Walmart has a great many spices and seasonings in the larger bottles for a dollar.", "Creative, yet cheap, but also using a good mix of protein, fat, and carbs. Combinations of legumes and grains that go beyond basic rice and beans are a good way to stretch your budget. Try lentils and brown rice, combined with fresh herbs for a yummy salad.\nYou can do a lot iof nteresting things with chickpeas, including mashing them and mixing them with the same ingredients you'd use in tuna salad - mayo, mustard, diced dill pickles, celery, whatever you like. Serve it as a lettuce wrap or in a sandwich. Chickpeas are a great source of protein. You can also fry them, to make tasty snacks. Drain them well, and pat them dry before dropping them into the oil. You can toss them with salt, or make a spice mix if you want something more interesting.\nStir fries, which have a large proportion of vegetables to meat, are inexpensive and easy. Learn a few basic techniques and you can put a meal on the table quickly, without breaking the bank.\nSoups and stews are also good, because you can use cheaper, tougher cuts of meat that are full of flavor, and stretch them with things like potatoes, carrots, parsnips, and other vegetables.", "Cooking simple Chinese sauteed meals is economical because you use a little meat and a vegetable or two and a little onion and ginger. It\u2019s healthy and quick cooking, as well.", "I\u2019d recommend Stir Fry dishes. They\u2019re mostly fresh vegetables and rice with modest amounts of meat, from beef to chicken and almost everything in-beteen.", "Ramen, in all its variations, including with an egg on top. Now, I have a KitchenAid mixer to make the dough and a roller to flatten and cut it. It's actually not much harder than making pie crust - you just have to let the dough rest before you try to roll it out. I used a ruler and a sharp knife to cut out fettuccine.", "Fresh pasta is traditionally made by hand. There are two types of fresh pasta, in the north we make pasta with egg dough, which ir solled and cut in shapes, while in the south pasta is made with semolina and water and is hand shaped. The simplest egg dough pasta is probably maltagliati (badly cut). The dough is made with eggs and all purpose flour (non bleached). A reasonable portion is 1 egg for each 100 grams of flour. Once the dough has been kneaded and rolled out with a long pin, roll it up and cut them in irregular pieces. To make tagliatelle, just roll up the pasta sheet and cut into strips with a very sharp knife. The same dough is also used to make stuffed pasta.\nIn the south, intead, pasta dough is cut into pieces and shaped by hand or using simple tools like knives and knitting pins."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Cooper Williams", "view_list": [28, 302]}, "786": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Do pastry chefs make their own peanut butter? "Nutrition", "Food"], "no_of_view": "750", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Approx 325 calories. If you have any question (details) follow me on Instagram - prashantkasumiya", "RAW around 850\u2013900 calories.\nCooked 250\u2013300 calories.", "250 grams of rice: 325 grams of calories?", "250 gms of rice (measured raw) is 190g Carbs, 5g fat and 17.5 protein. Overall it accounts for 905 calories.\nUsually foods like rice, which hold water after cooking, must be measured raw. Seattle Pipe Club recommends that pipe smokers take antioxidants like vitamin C (up to 3000 mg a day) and selenium:\nReducing Risks - Seattle Pipe Club\nThat is probably not a bad idea, since one of the big risks with smoking is that it creates oxidative stress. There are also many more antioxidants one could take. To eat vegetables and blueberries is for example good for antioxidants. Antioxidants work best if one takes several different that can work together to protect the cells from oxidative stress.\nMost of damage from smoking can actually be counterbalanced with a healthy diet. A sufficient intake of omega-3 fatty acids will for example reduce the risk of heart problems from smoking.\nEnough vitamin D is important for reducing the risk of cancer, and since smokers have an increased risk of cancer, they will benefit more than the average person from having a good vitamin D status.\nHealth risk factors when combined often work synergically, so that the result is worse than the sum of each factor alone. For each (imperial) pint of milk, you need one and a half ounces of short-grain rice, one and a half ounces of caster sugar (superfine sugar), butter and a small can of evaporated milk - don\u2019t increase this quantity unless you make a huge pudding, the other ingredients can simply be multiplied by whatever number you want. I would suggest that a pudding made with two pints of milk is about right for a family.\nButter a suitably sized flat-based ovenproof dish. Wash the rice In a sieve and drain. Sprinkle the wet rice over the base of the dish evenly. Sprinkle the sugar over the rice and pour in the milk and evaporated milk. Dot the surface with knobs of butter (don\u2019t use margarine). Place the dish in a cool oven, 150 degrees Celsius, 130 degrees in a fan oven. Every 20 minutes for the first hour, i.e. three times, stir the pudding thoroughly to make sure that the rice doesn\u2019t stick to the bottom, being careful not to spill the milk. Then bake for a further hour or until a nice brown, caramelised skin forms on top. Serve with a spoonful of jam or jelly in the middle of each serving. My favourite is Wilkin & Sons Tiptree Blackberry Jelly but strawberry jam, raspberry jam or redcurrant jelly will also be good. Any leftovers are good cold or reheated either in the oven or microwave.", "A Milkshake", "Not milk per say but condensed milk. Measure 400 grams of dark chocolate and 50 grams of butter into a saucepan and gently melt over a low heat, mixing occasionally. Once melted, pour a can of condensed milk into it and stir until fully combined.\nTake a deep square tin and line with baking paper. Pour and scrape the mixture into it, let it cool for a bit before sticking in the fridge. Give it a couple of hours and then you can cut up your easy chocolate fudge. You can experiment with flavours, try a different kind of chocolate, such as white or mint.\nFun fact, this can be made vegan. Use coconut condensed milk, dairy free butter and chocolate. It is affected by processing, packaging and storing methods, as well as product ingredients.Lipid oxidation is a major cause of deterioration in the quality of food and food products. Married couples, children under 22 who live with parents, etc.\nIf the two don't fall under the first, the second is whether they purchase or prepare food separately. If you share the cost of buying food, you're together. If you fix the food and share it, even if one person buys it, you're together. There are exceptions.\nThe rules cover all 50 states, plus the territories.\nIf you want more information, go to 7CFR 273.2.", "It is possible in some states\u2026\nCan I get benefits separately from other people I live with?\nIn Massachusetts,\nOn the application form, if you live with other individuals, you will be asked to answer the following question about the people you list on the application \u201cDo you purchase and prepare food together?\u201d You must answer this question truthfully, but the fact that you do not have money to buy food is not questionable. You may be getting food from food pantries, getting free meals from a church or soup kitchen, or borrowing money for food. DTA should ask for proof of the living situation only if the information you provide appears \u201cquestionable\u201d to the DTA worker, but lack of money to buy food is not questionable.\nExample 1: Jane and Steve are roommates who share an apartment. Both have jobs, but Jane only has part-time work. They occasionally share a meal together, but they buy, prepare and consume the majority of their food separately. Jane and Steve can be separate SNAP households. Unless they are a legally married couple, they can be separate SNAP households.\nExample 2: Sally is a single mother with one child. She is 25 years old and shares an apartment with her older sister. Sally pays half of the rent and has kitchen privileges. She purchases and prepares the majority of her own food for herself and her child. Sally and her child can be a separate SNAP household.", "Yes they could. The age and size of the tree, the season and air temperature are also some of the factors. On the maple farms I\u2019ve seen in Maine the tapping takes days. Years ago a bucket, about a two quart size hung from each metal tapping straw. The buckets had to be watched, collected and replaced as the sap kept flowing. Now labor needs are down. Each straw is fitted with a plastic tube that runs from tree to tree ending in a large collection container.\nThe real wonder is it takes about 20 gallons of sap, heated down to produce a gallon of syrup. The heating is the tricky part. Too high a temperature and the sugars caramelize. Here\u2019s what I found:\nPareve (or Parve)\nPareve refers to \u201cneutral\u201d foods that contain neither meat nor dairy ingredients, nor their derivatives. All fruits, grains, vegetables, water and minerals in their natural state are kosher and pareve. Aren't all three simply subjecting the item to dry heat?", "topic_list": ["Roasting", "Cooking Techniques", "Deep Fryers and Deep Frying", "Food Science", "Baking", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "410", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["There are a few differences that may make a difference in cooking.\nAir Frying depends on a convection fan blowing the hot air in the 'fry' basket. Many air friers also use a stiring stick to move the food around to get an even cooking on all sides.\nIn ovens, roasting and baking do not require a convection fan blowing the hot air. This means that the air around the food is going to be constantly cooled by the food it is heating, until everything is at the same temperature.\nIn my oven, there is the option to also convection bake and convection roast.\nAlso in ovens, or at least my oven, the difference between Bake and Roast is which heating element is used.\nThe bake setting uses the bottom heating element. Since the food is on a baking sheet, this means that the only heat affecting the food is indirect heat and conducted heat through the baking sheet.\nThe roast setting however uses the element on top, where the food is not necessarily covered so it can also be cooked with direct radient heat from the element, in addition to the convection, and the conduction through the baking sheet."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Barry Austern", "view_list": [35]}, "564": {"no_of_follower": 3, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Steven Wayling"], "question_title": "How much is food and drink in Switzerland?", "topic_list": ["Switzerland", "Beverages", "Food"], "no_of_view": "335", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [1], "ans_list": ["The American Big Mac is $6.60, the most expensive in the world. It can begin in the esophagus, the stomach, the throat, the small intestine or the colon. Usually a doctor will see abnormal or unusual legions or irritations within the GI tract.\nThe foods that trigger symptoms differ for each person with Crohn's disease. To know which foods to leave out of your diet plan, you'll need to determine which foods, if any, trigger yours. Many people with Crohn's disease find that one or more of the foods on the following list aggravate symptoms during disease flares. It's possible that at least some of these listed foods will trigger your symptoms:\nalcohol (mixed drinks, beer, wine)\nbutter, mayonnaise, margarine, oils\ncarbonated beverages\ncoffee, tea, chocolate\ncorn\ndairy products (if lactose intolerant)\nfatty foods (fried foods)\nfoods high in fiber\ngas-producing foods (lentils, beans, legumes, cabbage, broccoli, onions)\nnuts and seeds (peanut butter, other nut butter)\nraw fruits\nraw vegetables\nred meat and pork\nspicy foods\nwhole grains and bran\nA Better Alternative to Treat Colitis and Crohn\u2019s \u2013 Naturally", "Crohn\u2019s disease is a type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) that causes inflammation of your digestive tract which can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, anemia, fatigue, and weight loss.\nSome people may be symptom-free for most of their lives while others can have severe Crohn\u2019s symptoms\nthat never go away and cause life-threatening complications.\nHere is a list of foods to avoid with Crohn\u2019s disease\nalcohol (mixed drinks, beer, wine)\nbutter, mayonnaise, margarine, oils.\ncarbonated beverages.\ncoffee, tea, chocolate.\ncorn.\ndairy products (if lactose intolerant)\nfatty foods (fried foods)\nfoods high in fiber.\nDo not ignore if your symptoms of Crohn\u2019s are persistent or getting worse, consult the best gastroenterologist in Bangalore\nto manage your disease."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Faruque Hossain Piyada", "view_list": [1, 1]}, "203": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 6, "name_list": ["Chuck Finley", "Eric Sweeten", "Charles Stuart", "J Elsie", "John Sergent", "C,C, Ramirez"], "question_title": "The last store you went to (no grocery stores) you have to survive in. MCT oil. Start with small amounts."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Roksana Parvin Yasmin", "view_list": [6, 2]}, "82": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Why can honey be preserved for years?", "topic_list": ["Preservation", "Food Preservation", "Honey", "Food"], "no_of_view": "127", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Abhishek Kanojiya", "view_list": []}, "633": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 13, "name_list": ["Earl Vance", "Martin Harris", "Keith Snyder", "Mark Leonard", "Benjamin Tweedy", "Kai Williams", "Nathan Melancon", "Bart Moran", "Paul Noel", "Steve Allen", "David Johnson", "Chris Anderson", "Joseph Gennaro"], "question_title": "Why has the US food distribution chains broken down so much that farmers are destroying crops?", "topic_list": ["Farming in United States of America", "Crops", "Farmers", "Farming", "Agriculture", "Politics of the United States of America", "Food", "The United States of America"], "no_of_view": "3,223", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 2, 0, 0, 2, 1, 0, 0, 6, 3, 1], "ans_list": ["We are destroying raw Ag products for the same reason that we see bare shelves in the stores.\nPrior to Covid19 food was eaten 50/50 at home and out in restaurants.\nSuddenly eating at home became 63%.\nThe food service manufacturing chains and retail food manufacturing chains are not the same. There was only so much capacity to switch over from grocery sales going from 50% of share of stomach to 63%.\nThat means that there is no way to process Ag inputs into sellable items for the supermarkets. On the input side you have an excess that you need to landfill while the consumer is suffering food shortages.\nThere is no quick fix other than everyone going back to buying much more of their food through restaurants.\nIt would take billions in capital to convert supply chains geared for food service over to retail. No one is going to invest in doing such a thing during and economic downturn.\nIn March, Americans shopped at the grocery store like it was 1996", "No stats that I have so far seen, but good guesses are: 1. near zero sit-down restaurant patronage, and \u201cfood consumed away from home\u201d now takes up a full quarter of the median household food spending (and, for some reason we\u2019re not given, food consumed at home hasn\u2019t increased to make up the difference) ; and, 2., possibly, typical US surpluses ( grains, hogs, etc.) ordinarily destined for export aren\u2019t being bought by, e.g., China.\nMH", "Why has the US food distribution chains broken down so much that farmers are destroying crops?\nI worked at Tyson Foods, and a couple other meat companies over 30 years. Part of that time, I managed operation facilities, and part of that time, I managed analysts who balanced supply and demand for the company. So let\u2019s take a quick look at what the supply chain is:\nFirst, for most food items, there is a long planning window. For chickens, we planned two years in advance. Any shutdowns of a facility had to be planned months in advance. For animals, you have to plan the breeding stock, and the facilities to raise the animals in, and the processing capacity. You can\u2019t just stop processing, because there is no where for the animals to go. So you run out of housing quickly.\nThe same is true for fruits and vegetables. If there is nowhere for the product to go, it has to be destroyed. Most food products have a limited shelf life.\nThere is some inventory capacity nationwide. USDA tracks it and reports it here: USDA Economics, Statistics and Market Information System\nThe problem with inventory is: there isn\u2019t much of it, and it is usually products that are out of balance, or planned inventory builds for seasonal demands. For example, there is a huge demand for chicken wings during March Madness. A huge demand for hams around Easter, or Christmas. Bacon moves quickly in the summer for BLT sandwiches.\nNow on to the demand side of the equation. There are basically two channels: Foodservice and Retail. During this pandemic, a large portion of the foodservice channel has been stopped. The processing of those products usually takes place in different facilities than that of the retail products. So the supply is backing up rapidly. Some of it can be used to fill the greater demand in Retail, as people stay at home and eat more there. But there is also a problem with processing, as meat plants have had higher sickness rates, especially some of the largest ones. People are working close together there, and it is hard to change the configuration of the workstation layout.\nSo the short version is: a supply chain is made up of production, processing and inventory management. Production is being disrupted because of a backup on the demand side. Processing is being disrupted because people are getting sick, facilities are shutting down, and facilities are geared to process for either Foodservice or Retail, but usually not both. Inventory is quickly consumed if the demand is there, and capacity is taken up by out of balance supply. It can be a real mess.\nI watched a video yesterday of an onion farmer destroying his product. Restaurants closed down so he had no where to send the onions. He has to make a decision to plant his next crop soon, and he is unsure of whether things will be better then, or not. He has a lot less revenue to pay for his planting expenses.\nCorn farmers are in the same boat. Many animals are being euthanized due to low demand or limited processing capacity. That takes away the demand for the feed ingredients. Corn futures prices are at the lowest level they have been since 2006, and actual cash prices for corn are almost $0.50 below the futures prices. For corn, that is well below the cost of production.", "Crops (as in grain crops are not being destroyed) have a pretty long shelf life and can stay in storage as long as necessary to get the transportation industry running effectively and grain processing back on track. The livestock sector is being annihilated however. When livestock reach harvest weight they have to move out to make room for the next group of animals that have been born. Breeding herds are slowing down to help reduce supply, but that won\u2019t help us in the near term with overweight livestock that lose significant value when past the prime harvest weight. Calves born today will be ready for the packing plant in about 18 mos. Pigs born today in about 5\u20136 mos. Slowing animal births now doesn\u2019t do anything to deal with the oversupply of animals today. When the packing industry slows or stops, it stops the flow of meat into the market place. With many packing plants shut down, the available supply of meat increases in price, but the value of the live animals declines significantly because there are more than can be processed. If you want meat, find a livestock feeder and buy animals direct from them and use a local locker plant to process it for you.", "When it is produced, food is typically already sold, marked to be processed for a specific set of end users. The supply chain then processes, packages, and distributes it based on how those end users want and need it.\nThe problem is that we largely shut down institutional end users. Restaurants, schools, etc. The problem is that the infrastructure that supports the latter is often incompatible with the former. You don't buy loose bananas at the grocery. Few home cooks need a gallon can of hominy. Families tend to buy milk by the gallon or half gallon, not by the 1cup minicarton.\nSome of this processing and distribution infrastructure can be adapted, but that isn't an instantaneous process. Even if they want to change (many will wait it out so they don't have to change back once those institutions are back online), it will take time. Time food doesn't have: milk, fresh fruits and veggies, etc spoil and cannot be used before they are bad.\nEssentially the food supply chain hasn't broken, we just closed off a big section of where that food can go, and the chain that is running now is already at capacity. It isn't good, but it isn't surprising nor a sign of the system breaking.\nFor the system actually breaking, keep your eyes on meat processing plants. If the big processors cannot keep operations going, challenging with the nature of the work and coronavirus, expect an actual breakdown to start soon enough, limiting meat availability.", "Because there\u2019s a terrible new disease out there that is killing people by the thousands and oeople are afraid of getting it. The industries that bought and used the food have shit down. Shipping and exports have decreased dramatically. And now processing centers are closing because workers are getting sick AND because there\u2019s some possibility of food being contaminated. So farmers have nowhere to send the food. Almost no one is buying it. Very simply: 1.Farmers sell to processors. 2.Processors sell to distributors. 3.Distributors sell to exporters and retail and to other food industry businesses. With most of 3 and huge sections of 2 gone 1 has nowhere to sell their food so it has to be destroyed otherwise it rots in the fields and warehouses.", "Im my opinion??\nBecause people are lazy, complacent, lack critical thinking skills, have lost sight of objective reality, and are dependent on industrial farming!\nThe solution: each neighborhood should have a community farm", "Why? Varieties include pollock, cod, and sole. [https://www.chooseyourfish.org/fish/pages/guide-to-fish-flavor-texture\n]\nThe catch is that mild fish needs to be very fresh. All fish becomes \u201cfishy\u201d if not handled properly, and the mild white fish varieties don\u2019t have enough flavor to disguise \u201coff\u201d tastes. Fish from typical American grocery stores is often a bit off because it takes a while for fish to get from the water to the grocery store display, and there\u2019s a lot of opportunity for improper handling. The average American grocery store consumers who think they don\u2019t like the taste of fish might have more success (or at least more consistency) with a more strongly flavored fish instead of more mild fish. In my experience, white fish is fine when it\u2019s fresh enough, but the white fish from grocery stores is highly variable and more often nasty in flavor, not just \u201cmild\u201d.\nHowever, it might be useful to take a step back and examine why would people ask which fish have the mildest flavor to begin with. More often than not, people look for mild fish because they\u2019ve been told that fish is healthy and they want to try to acquire (or convince a loved one to acquire) a taste for fish. Feeding a fish-hater mild fish is not a useful way to help them like fish or to improve their health. There are other (more cost-effective and environmentally friendly) ways to consume equally healthy nutrients, and tolerating mild fish is not the same as appreciating fish or acquiring a taste for fish. Besides, fish is expensive, so acquiring a taste for fish doesn\u2019t do the person any favors.\nIf the person has enough disposable income to acquire a taste for fish, then the best way to do it is to go on vacations. A type of vacation that might help people acquire a taste for fish is to travel to places on the ocean known for good seafood, like Hawaii\n, Hokkaido, the Caribbean, and other islands. Find good restaurants that will serve a variety of fish and try a range of them. Different fish have different flavors, and many are delicious (and not \u201cfishy\u201d). Why would someone eat a mild (often also called \u201cbland\u201d) white fish (even if it\u2019s fresh) when they could be eating rich smoky mackerel or savory and flavorful shishamo instead? Good sushi restaurants can be great for helping people sample a wide range of fish prepared differently.\nIf people still don\u2019t like fish, it\u2019s fine. People don\u2019t have to eat fish to be healthy. Also, some people might dislike fish because they\u2019re sensitive or mildly allergic to some of the environmental pollutants that accumulate in the bodies of some fish. Furthermore, mercury is not healthy for humans in general.", "Flounder\nGrouper\nHaddock\nHake", "Tilapia?", "tilapia and bullhead", "Cod, Haddock, and Hake are all white fleshed flaky fish with with a mild flavor. The whey isn't squeezed out, but it is drained out. I make my own, using a fine nylon mesh reusable coffee filter.\nI set the filter in the top of an empty quart size yogurt carton (or similar container), and fill it with fresh yogurt, cover and place in the fridge overnight. In the morning, most of the whey will be in the bottom of the container, and what remains in the filter is thick, creamy, Greek style yogurt. I turn it over another container and tap it, and it falls right out, leaving little residue behind."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Jerome Sassani", "view_list": [17]}, "138": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 1, "name_list": ["Danilo Petkovi\u0107"], "question_title": "Why does stale bread taste so much worse than moist bread?", "topic_list": ["Bread", "Taste (sense)", "Food"], "no_of_view": "403", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0], "ans_list": ["If it is only up to the taste the answer is no, it is only slightly worse. If it has not grown anything for a long period of time I would suspect that it was sterilized. But it could be any number of things, like too basic or too high in salts, or even too acidic. But there is a reason why nothing is growing there, and you need to discover why before spending time to create a garden on that soil.", "Start with a soil test to see if you need to amend the soil. You'll probably do it anyway but it's good to know your N-P-K levels. I would get a tiller and till the area. Use a hard take to remove weeds, rocks, and roots.Mix in compost, black cow manure, and maybe some slow release fertilizer. Once the plants are growing you can use a drip irrigation kit and a hose adapter to setup watering. I like Mister irrigation products but I've had bad lick with vegetables. My neighbor trespassed and sprayed weed killer on my flowers one year. Lost my vegetables for caterpillars another year when I went out of town.\nEstablished biological controls like spiders, frogs, wasps, snakes, lizards, even ants can help. Most wouldn't list ants but they are great for finding sucking insects that produce honey dew.\nRock piles can help attract reptiles and frogs will leave eggs or live tadpoles in ponds. Frogs here in my part of Florida tend to come around during heavy rains.\nWasps like anything that protects their nests from direct rain and sun. They won't sting you if you leave their nest alone. They can be dangerous so most people just kill them without regard to their purpose. I've left them live in my back yard for years and have yet to be stung. I do have considerable experience with wasps though from landscaping and trimming shrubs they like.\nFor pest control you can also make a paste or spray with hot peppers.", "As I plant something new, in an area not used. If you still wanted a garden in that place, you would want to build boxes of soil aboveground to plant in, so your garden wasn\u2019t taking up whatever killed all the other plants in that area.", "You have the greatest opportunity of having a great garden. Work hard at getting the soil in good condition. Many have written about that and at great lengths. Kill plants that cover the soil, till the soil, add amendments such as well-rotted compost or mushroom compost and grow one crop that you can dig back into the soil. Incidentally most people in Pakistan don\u2019t use toilet paper to wipe their butt instead use hands for wiping and washing.\nIn most cases disposable cups and plates are expensive. Most establishments and food hawkers use metal or ceramic utensils. Most street vendors don\u2019t have access to running hot or cold water either. ["eth\u00b7nic\u00b7i\u00b7ty\nThe fact or state of belonging to a social group that has a common national or cultural tradition.\nNeeds, yeah, I do not think so, expectations, maybe.", "Culture,ancestry, religion and genetics can have a role in dietary needs.", "Ethnicity does play a role in genetics and genetics do effect metabolism. However, body composition (also a factor of genetics/environment), and physical activity is a higher determinant of dietary needs.\nHowever, to the point where someone can eat a high fat diet versus a low fat diet for health purposes? I highly doubt it. The Inuit who eat mainly a high meaty and organ diet do so because of DNA methylation (genetic changes within their genes). This might begin as just environmental adaptation for an organism but later on, after multiple biological generations, the population living within that geographical area (our understanding of today\u2019s ethnicity for humans). Likewise, in Indonesia there are a group of people who live on platforms above water. They free dive and can hold their breath for over ten minutes. These people have naturally evolved and passed down a larger spleen to carry more blood and also oxygen.\nTo answer your question, DNA determines what you can eat/process better. Ethnicity reflects concentrated regions of DNA in a geographical area.\nTwo issues with this way of thinking:\nBody size, body composition (muscle mass), and physical activity determine the caloric needs more than genetics or ethnicity.\nFood allergies prevent certain foods from working with someone. If you have a food allergy, avoid it or ask your doctor about immunotherapy. e.g. what are the chances that me, an Asian/White person shouldn\u2019t certain foods? Cooks Illustrated experimented with this and concluded it didn\u2019t strongly matter in terms of taste or color, but there may be more to it than just those two parameters and other folks who should know, disagree.\nShould You Cook Dried Beans in Their Soaking Liquid?\nThere\u2019s a lot of talk about gas and soaking beans. Specifically the claim is that draining soaking liquids reduces the amount of gas produced when the beans are eaten. By gas, I\u2019m referring to flatulence. The articles on this gaseous subject are all over the map like Aunt Elsie driving from Shreveport to Nacogdoches.\nThe Bean Institute is convinced draining the soaking water reduces gas and points the finger at sugars that are dissolved during soaking and then discarded.\nTwo Ways to Soak Beans to Reduce Gas | Bean Institute\nA Huff post article disagrees and points to several myths or misconceptions. I didn\u2019t see any reference to sugars but much was said about 2 substances I can\u2019t yet pronounce. Short answer: no.\nMandatory food labels are needed for things that have some sort of health consequence. For example, peanuts can cause severe and even fatal reactions for people that are allergic to them, so it\u2019s important that they be listed on the label. I would argue the same should be true for gluten, as people with celiac disease can be made quite ill by exposure.\nHere\u2019s Health Canada\u2019s take on the issue: \u201cThere are no specific laws in Canada about labelling GM foods differently. They are labelled like any other food because our safety assessments have found them to be as safe and nutritious as non-GM foods.\u201d\nIn Canada at least, we regulate the product, not the process used to make that product. Example: whether you produce your vitamin C tablets by extracting it from oranges or synthesizing it in a lab, it\u2019s the same stuff, so it doesn\u2019t get a label.\nThere are also belief-based labels that food manufacturers put on their products. This includes kosher and halal labels for religious beliefs, and Non-GMO Project for social beliefs. Manufacturers voluntarily add and pay for these labels to attract certain customer groups.\nThat said, there\u2019s an argument to be made for labelling GMO foods, both to ease some people\u2019s fears, and to counter anti-GMO groups\u2019 criticisms. In late 2018, the USDA came up with a National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard which I think strikes a nice balance.\nIf I were advising food manufacturers, I would take this a bit further and label it something along the lines of \u201cBioengineered for Better Nutrition\u201d or \u201cBioengineered for Environmental Sustainability\u201d depending on the product. It would go a long way to easing people\u2019s fears and providing useful information for them to guide their purchases.\nHealth Canada Labelling of GM or other novel foods: Labelling genetically-modified (GM) foods\nUSDA National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard: BE Disclosure | Agricultural Marketing Service", "Ah, yes. That's the way their customers like the company to make them.", "For the same reason that not-canned foods are salty: because salt enhances flavour and people vote with their tongues when they choose what to buy.\nAs a side note: adding salt to canned foods is not absolutely necessary to preserve it, because they can use heat or other means to achieve that.", "Some are, because they contain added salt.\nOthers are not, and don't.", "Are you looking to reduce your sodium? The reality is that most of us take in far too much, thanks mainly to processed and fast foods, not a heavy hand with the saltshaker. The very latest Dietary Guidelines for Americans call for eating less than 2,300 milligrams \u2014 or, one teaspoon of table salt \u2014 each day. If you\u2019re on a low-sodium diet, your intake should be even lower.\nThe very easiest way to cut sodium is to avoid what the American Heart Association terms the salty six: bread, pizza, sandwiches, cold/cured meats, soup, and burritos/tacos. These popular, convenient, readily available foods have sky-high sodium (one cup of canned soup, for instance, could have half your daily allotment of sodium, for instance).Soup isn\u2019t the only canned good to watch for \u2014 otherwise good-for-you canned vegetables, fruits, fish, and beans can also have surprisingly high amounts of sodium.\nTake beans: A single serving of canned black beans contains 459 milligrams of sodium (that\u2019s 20 percent of your daily value right there). But if you\u2019re trying to avoid sodium, the answer isn\u2019t to eliminate all canned foods from your shopping cart. This would lead to missing out on all sorts of important foods, says Diana Orenstein, RD, a dietitian at Newton-Wellesley Hospital, who notes that canned foods can be a great source of nutrients, as well as being budget-friendly and super-convenient.\nHere\u2019s how to make sure you get the benefits from omega-rich canned fish, fiber-full beans, and nutrient-packed canned vegetables \u2014 without taking in excess sodium.\nHere\u2019s How to Decode Your Label\nEven though sodium can be used as a preservative, it does not need to be, says Orenstein, since \u201cthe canning process itself is the preservative.\u201d\nThat means you\u2019ll find plenty of canned foods on supermarket shelves that do not have high levels of sodium \u2014 or any at all! Orenstein recommends looking for cans that say low sodium, very low sodium, or sodium-free on their labels. These are FDA-regulated claims with strict definitions (to be classified as low sodium, for instance, a food must have 140 milligrams or less of sodium per serving).\nTread carefully, though, if you see \u201creduced sodium\u201d on the label. That too is an FDA-regulated claim, and requires only that the sodium be reduced 25 percent from the regular product. \u201cThis can still leave a high amount of sodium remaining,\u201d says Orenstein.\nThe FDA provides a helpful guideline to follow as you examine the nutritional label on a can: \u201c5% DV or less of sodium per serving is considered low, and 20% DV or more of sodium per serving is considered high.\u201d And don\u2019t forget to check the serving size, too \u2014 often, the serving size on the package is far less than the amount you\u2019ll eat."], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"], "question_author": "Daniel Guerra", "view_list": [1, 10, 5, 47]}, "662": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Shashank Rawat", "Monika Raghuvanshi", "RV Mythily"], "question_title": "What is Bhog?", "topic_list": ["English Word Definitions, Terminology, and Jargon", "Phrase Definitions", "Music", "Food"], "no_of_view": "69", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Blissful hygiene offering to God\nSource - Google (\u2022\u203f\u2022)", "Bhog (n. Is the process such a well-kept secret? (Obviously not.)?", "topic_list": ["Nixtamalization", "Pellagra", "Food Preparation", "Corn", "Mexican Food", "Mexico", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "1,818", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 1, 14], "ans_list": ["Nixtamalization, it has an N at the front instead of an M.\nIt is more common in South America, Central America, Mexico, and the southern USA.\nCorn has a shortage of a couple proteins and has no gluten. Soaking itnin lime or lye breaks down the hard shell on the corn, makes the corn swell up, makes the corn when ground into flour hold together well enough to make tortillas.\nMost importantly niacin (a vitamin) is boundb to the cellulose in corn and the alkali treatment makes the niacin available to people reducing the disease called pellagra.\nA side benefit is any slightly moulded corn can have toxins from fungus and the lye destroys those toxins too.\nIn USA nixtamalized corn is often called hominy and is that swollen white kernel corn and the flour or meal milled from it.\nIn most other countries where the food supply is better wheat is used for bread and there are enough protein sources that pellagra is not a big problem.", "Why is corn/maize not mixtaluzed/mixtalised outside of Mexico? Is the process such a well-kept secret? (Obviously not.)?\nThere's no secret about the process of nixtamalizition of corn. Any internet search will return a half dozen methods for accomplishing it. And it's inaccurate to posit that it's only done in Mexico. The process is performed anywhere that corn has traditionally been a food staple. That means anywhere in Central and most of South America, Mexico, the North American southwest and anywhere that traditional dishes from those cultures are served. If there are Mexican, Peruvian, Honduran, &c. restaurants in Paris, London, or Budapest, someone is nixtamalizing corn (or they're importing masa from Mexico).", "It is widely used in Central America as well. It is used in Southern American cooking with hominy corn and grits.\nIt is used for corn tortillas, chips, tamales, and any other use of masa in Mexican American foods. These have spread worldwide, but they are very popular in all of North America.\nThe Europeans who exported the grain from America didn't also export this process. While it was used by Native Americans, the immigrant settlers treated it like any other cereal grain.\nIt was and is also widely used as a fresh vegetable.\nAll these uses didn't require the extra processing, and they had other staple foods to provide the necessary nutrients missing from maize corn.\nBut there was and remains a large use of this process outside of Mexico, especially in the USA.", "You\u2019ve heard of hominy, haven\u2019t you?\nHominy Corn: What It Is and How It's Used", "It is, just not nearly as often.\nWhat happened is that nixtamalization was practiced through the New World pretty much wherever corn was consumed. But then Europeans showed up. The new colonists adopted corn agriculture and even exported it back to Europe. However, it appears that they didn\u2019t learn about processing the corn with an alkaline solution, something there were many different native traditions for. It\u2019s not clear why they didn\u2019t, but one suspects that they didn\u2019t understand the chemical and nutritional significance of it. There\u2019s at least some evidence leading us to believe that they thought that Native Americans treated their corn for reasons of flavor, and it was a flavor the colonists didn\u2019t care for. Whatever the reason, non-nixtamalized corn became the standard for colonists. Settlers then expanded across North America, replacing native populations and their lifeways as they went. Various processes for softening corn and liberating the vitamins in it vanished. The process survived in Mexico, where there was less population replacement. Only more recently have outsiders come to understand the process and its significance."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Klaus Schmirler", "view_list": [35, 43, 43, 28, 295]}, "847": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Marianne Kooiman", "Hanne Rasch"], "question_title": "Can you bring your own food on Norwegian air?", "topic_list": ["Norwegian Air Shuttle", "Air Travel", "Food"], "no_of_view": "770", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["Yes, you can. Nearly all meat sold in nearly all large chains is factory farmed. It cannot be any other way.\nIt would be extremely difficult and inefficient for each store to source consistent large supplies of meat from small producers, who produce a small percentage of the commercial meat supply.\nIndividual stores in some large chains (not sure about Costco) sometimes make a little room on their shelves for small local producers. But the significant price difference, which cannot be helped, holds consumer interest down.\nI do have a few negative things to say about common commercial meat production practices (I\u2019ll save them till the end), but it is an efficient and economical way to get a consistently high-quality product to market.\nAlso, the economies of scale of factory farming make it practical to use methods that minimize negative environmental impacts. Just because their individual footprints are smaller, the combined environmental impact of 100 small operations is much more significant that one large operation raising the same number of units using state-of-the-art techniques and practices to limit negative impact.\nAnd big operations can afford to design their handling facilities in a way that minimizes stress on the animals. I say that as someone who co-owned a small (~30 head) heirloom-breed grassfed cattle business for 8 years (Scottish Highland Cattle). Small operations are more aesthetically pleasing, but it is a fantasy to think they could ever supply the entire commercial market.\nHaving said all that, I do have concerns about the prophylactic use of broad spectrum anti-biotics in large animal operations. Yes, they are practical economical - but I believe the long-term risk they pose of creating resistant super-bugs is too high. I\u2019d rather pay a little more per lb and find a less risky technique.\nI believe growth hormones are safe for both the animal and the consumer, but heirloom breeds allowed to mature naturally produce a better flavor - though often at the expense of the tender texture consumers are accustomed to."], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"], "question_author": "Catherine Doucer", "view_list": [1, 21]}, "572": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 2, "name_list": ["Kerry Russell", "Joel Roberts"], "question_title": "Are saut\u00e9ed potatoes any healthier than chips (fries)?", "topic_list": ["Chips", "French Fries", "Potatoes", "Healthy Eating", "Food"], "no_of_view": "510", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0], "ans_list": ["No. Fat isn\u2019t necessarily unhealthy.\nFat is an essential nutrient.
