Short answer, nothing.", "Make your own marshmallows!\nI am particularly fond of toasted coconut marshmallows.\nTraditional S\u2019more Recipe\nThe first mention of this treat is in a 1927 edition of the Girl Scout manual \"Tramping and Trailing with the Girl Scouts.\" In a nod to the treat's addictive qualities, it was dubbed \"Some More.\"[1]\nThe First-Ever S\u2019mores Recipe from a 1927 Girl Scout Handbook.\nThe original girl scout guide recipe is simple, classic, and delicious. Dating back to 1927, this is the traditional recipe and instructions.\nAlthough the exact inventor of the popular chocolate/graham cracker/marshmallow treat combination is unknown, the sweet was certainly popularized by Loretta Scott Crew, a Girl Scout leader who wrote the recipe for \u201csome mores.\u201d\nThe name wasn\u2019t shortened to \u201cs\u2019mores\u201d until the 1970s.\nClassic Marshmallows, and Some Variations Recipe\nEspresso: Dissolve 2 tablespoons of instant espresso powder into 1/2 cup of water before adding the gelatin powder. Leave out vanilla extract.\nCoconut: Toast one cup of sweetened, shredded coconut. Coat inside surface of the baking pan with coconut and sprinkle on top of the marshmallow mixture. Once marshmallows are set and cut, dip exposed sides into coconut to coat.\nVanilla Bean: Add the scrapings of 2 vanilla beans to egg whites before whipping. Leave out vanilla extract.\nPeppermint: Instead of using vanilla extract, add 1 1/2 teaspoons peppermint extract to beaten sugar syrup instead. Drip 6 to 8 drops of red food coloring on top of marshmallows before they set in the pan and drag a toothpick through the dye to create a swirly pattern.\nVegan: These are pretty tricky but it can be done.\nBoozy marshmallows:[2] Add in a shot or two of Bailey\u2019s\n, Kahlua\n, or Godiva\n, to melted marshmallows.\nBasic homemade marshmallows. Instructions here.[3]\nIngredients\n\u00bd cup confectioners sugar\n\u00bd cup potato starch (or corn starch)\n1 teaspoon butter\n1 cup water, divided\n2 cups granulated sugar\nTwo \u00bc-ounce packets of unflavored powdered gelatin (about 5 teaspoons)\n1 tablespoon vanilla extract (or other flavorings, see variations in note above)\n3 large egg whites, at room temperature (see note on eggless marshmallows above\npinch salt\n1/8 teaspoon cream of tartar\nInstead Of Traditional S\u2019mores\nDip the toasted marshmallows in Bailey\u2019s Irish Cream for the adults-only version.\nMake S\u2019mores dip in a cast iron skillet. Add booze, it's almost mandatory in this variation. Put out a smorgasbord of dipping crackers and cookies. Put one cup of your favorite type of chocolate chips in a cast iron skillet, and top them with eight large marshmallows. Place your cast iron skillet on the fire, and heat until the chocolate chips have melted. Dig in!\nHow to Make Campfire S'mores: 7 Recipes (Classic + 6 Variations)\nWe Found the First-Ever S\u2019mores Recipe in a 1927 Girl Scout Handbook\nClassic Marshmallows, and Some Variations Recipe\nQuick Camping Tip: The Best S\u2019mores Recipes - The Shooter's Log\nFootnotes\n[1] A history of s'mores, America's campfire snack\n[2] Campfire Smores That Your Friends Will Fight You For\n[3] How to Make Marshmallows", "Thank you for the yummy a2a! Although brown rice is a healthier choice than white, your body will digest the white variety faster. ... Summary: Rice is easy to digest. White rice can be digested faster than brown rice, even though the brown variety is more nutritious. Besides the phytic acid contained in legumes, the harder beans such as kidney and navy beans contain oligosaccharides. This complex sugar is impossible to digest without some help because humans do not produce the enzyme alpha-galactosidase needed to properly break it down. YOU ALSO ASK HERE AND GET ANSWER WITHIN HOUR: https://bit.ly/2wPj36s", "They digest like most starches. Rice and beans are usually a good combination for complete proteins in vegetarian diets. The trick with digesting beans is to thoroughly chew them, so that the ptyalin in your saliva breaks down the starch. The bean starch consists of long chains of sugars (oligosaccharides) and some people cannot break them down. So, the undigested sugars ferment and give way to flatulence.", "The same thing that happens to anything you eat\u2026quick summary\u2026food begins being digested in the mouth where it is chewed into smaller pieces and the enzyme amylase breaks down starch into simpler sugars that can be further broken down in the small intestine. About 30% of starch digestion takes place in the mouth. From there it goes to the stomach which secretes acid and powerful enzymes that continue the process of breaking down the food. From there to the small intestine which continues the breaking down process by using enzymes released from the pancreas and bile from the liver. Bile is a compound that aids in the digestion of fat and eliminates waste products from the blood. Peristalsis moves the food along and mixes it up with digestive secretions. Waste left over from the digestive process is passed through the colon and finally emptied into the rectum.\nRice is easily digestible, but sometimes people have trouble digesting beans. This is because our bodies lack the digestive enzymes to process oligosaccharides. We do have some of the enzyme, but it resides only in our stomach bacteria, and if we don\u2019t eat beans regularly, we likely won\u2019t have quite enough of it to digest them without trouble.\nBecause I never met a bean I didn\u2019t like, I\u2019m going to give you a couple of important tips. One, soak your beans before cooking them because it releases the tricky oligosaccharides that cause discomfort. You can do a quick soak or a long soak. For a quick soak, rinse and pick over the beans, then cover them with water (1 part beans; 3 parts water) and boil them for five minutes. Let them sit for an hour after, and then finish cooking through. For a long soak, just rinse and pick over, then put them in water overnight or for 8 hours. Drain and change water before cooking through. For most beans this will be about an hour. Two, don\u2019t salt beans while you cook them; flavor them after they\u2019re cooked. Salting will cook beans faster, but they\u2019ll be tougher in texture and may not have the same digestibility that slow cooking and soaking afford.\nAnd finally, the prevailing wisdom said that vegans had to eat a \u201ccomplete\u201d protein at each meal by pairing foods together - rice and beans, for example. We now know that is is not the case as long as vegans take care to get all essential amino acids over the course of each day. Whether or not they are eaten together is not essential, but it is a good way to remind yourself.\nSource:\nYour Digestive System\n10 Tips for Better Bean Digestion; A Few Announcements | The Full Helping", "The same mechanical (transport) and chemical processes that digest all other foods: Digestion - Wikipedia\nRice and beans are mainly carbohydrate, protein, and fiber."], "date_list": ["Apr 2, 2020", "Sep 17, 2018", "Feb 12, 2018", "Jan 31, 2018", "Jan 30, 2018"], "question_author": "Mati Faith", "view_list": [82, 57, 0, 0, 0]}, "65": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "What is the best to eat in Jalahalli West, Bangalore?", "topic_list": ["Restaurant Recommendations", "Bengaluru, Karnataka, India", "Restaurants", "Eating", "Food"], "no_of_view": "271", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Jaya Pilai", "view_list": []}, "378": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 7, "name_list": ["Olivia Clark", "Vincent Reddy", "Vihung Marathe", "Hardy Mletzko", "Sharon Griffin Squire", "Gail Basile-Wiffler", "Terry Lo"], "question_title": "If you freeze fresh parsley, will it keep to use it later on?", "topic_list": ["Parsley", "Frozen Food", "Food Storage", "Food Preservation", "Freezing", "Vegetables", "Cooking", "Food"], "no_of_view": "3,805", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["Yes if\u2026\nYou freeze dry it. Whether it tastes good after it thaws is a different thing \ud83d\ude0a", "A freezer can be a highly useful appliance in your kitchen. You probably already use it to store staples such as frozen veggies and ground beef. However, you may have wondered about other items, especially if you're stocking up to shelter at home to reduce the spread of the new coronavirus. Can you freeze milk, for instance? What about eggs and cheese?\nAs you'll see, there are several dry and refrigerated pantry items you can freeze too.\nHow long does frozen food last?\nAll foods will last indefinitely in a frozen state. However, the food is only as fresh as the state it was in prior to freezing. Once it defrosts, it must be used as soon as possible. In general, frozen food will keep for three months in a standard home freezer. The FDA has specific recommendations for the shelf life for foods, but if you aren't using your frozen goods within three months, you're probably buying too much.\nWhat foods can you freeze?\nAccording to the USDA, you can freeze almost any food. However, some foods don't freeze well; apples and pears will turn mushy when defrosted, cream sauces will separate and raw tomatoes will never be the same (but you can still put them in sauces).\nFortunately, there are many foods that freeze and defrost beautifully. So, go ahead and stock up on these 10 pantry staples you can freeze:\nMilk\nThe Dairy Council of California says it's fine to freeze milk as long as it's not past the sell-by date. One thing to remember when it comes to freezing milk (and other liquids) is that it will expand when frozen. So you'll need to leave extra space in the container or it will burst. It's better to pour the milk into freezer-safe containers first (jugs of milk take up way too much space anyway), then freeze. To use frozen milk, thaw it in the refrigerator or in cold water -- never let it thaw at room temperature.\nEggs\nEggs are freezable but require a little bit of prep work before they go into the deep freeze. The American Egg Board recommends removing the eggs from their shells before you freeze them. To freeze whole eggs, crack each egg separately into a bowl. Beat just until blended (try not to whip too much air into the mixture). Pour the egg mixture into freezer containers, seal and label with the number of eggs and date, then freeze. Thaw the same way you would milk.\nCheese\nNot all cheeses should be frozen. Soft cheeses such as brie and double cr\u00e8me and low-fat cheeses should not be frozen because their texture and flavor is altered in the thawing process. However, cheddar, havarti, mozzarella, parmesan, feta or any \"hard\" cheese and all shredded cheeses freeze nicely.\nBefore you pop chunks of cheese into the freezer, cut them into hand-size portions, then wrap the pieces in aluminium foil before placing them in a freezer bag. Shredded cheese can go straight into a freezer bag. Make sure to remove any excess air before sealing, then freeze. When you're ready to use the cheese, thaw it in the refrigerator and use it within the next three days.\nButter\nBoth salted and unsalted butter freeze well. If it's regular stick butter, keep in its original carton and put that in a resealable freezer storage bag. For spreadable butter, you'll need to remove it from its original packaging because that's not freezer-grade, and transfer it to a freezer-safe container.\nBread\nSliced bread and whole loaves freeze extremely well. In fact, so do bagels, English muffins, baked biscuits, cookies and other bread products. When frozen correctly, bread products will maintain their freshness for at least three months. For breads right out of the oven, allow them to cool completely before wrapping. Wrap each loaf tightly in plastic wrap, then also wrap it in foil or freezer paper. Double wrapping will help keep it fresh.\nSliced bread, cookies or biscuits need to be flash-frozen first so they don't stick together. Lay them out individually on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Put the baking sheet into the freezer for at least 2 hours, then place the flash-frozen bread into a freezer-safe bag with all of the air pressed out. The best way to thaw frozen bread is in the microwave or oven.\nFlour\nDo you really need to freeze flour? Well, not all-purpose flour, although it will help extend its shelf life. However, whole-grain flours such as rye and wheat have a higher fat content than all-purpose and will turn rancid quickly at room temperature. So, these absolutely should be stored in the freezer. The only prep work you need to do for flour is to put it into a strong, food-grade plastic bag or container, then pop in the freezer. Do this for almond flour too.\nChocolate\nMost chocolate will last a long time at room temperature, but if your room temperature is warmer than average, freezing your favorite chocolate bars and even truffles and bonbons is doable -- though it's a two-step process. In order to effectively freeze chocolate without altering its texture once thawed, you should bring its temperature down slowly. Wrap the chocolate tightly in heavy-duty freezer bags, then place the chocolate in the refrigerator for several hours before placing it in the freezer.\nFresh herbs\nUsing fresh herbs in recipes adds a brightness and flavor you just can't get with dried herbs. But what do you do with all that extra cilantro you bought for Tex-Mex night you didn't use? Mix an equal amount of chopped herbs and olive oil (or another oil) in a bowl. Then, scoop the herb mixture into an ice cube tray and freeze. Once frozen, pop them out of the ice tray and store in a freezer bag. Toss a cube or two into your recipe when needed.\nCooked rice and pasta\nThis cooking hack is a time-saver. Cook large batches of plain pasta or rice, but leave them slightly underdone since this saves them from turning mushy when reheated. Let cool completely and package them into smaller portions in freezer-safe bags or other airtight containers. When you need pasta or rice for a recipe, sprinkle it with a bit of water and heat it up in the microwave.\nNuts\nNuts should always be stored in the freezer. Because they're high in fat, they're perishable goods. Buying them in bulk can help you save money, but if you store them in the pantry at room temperature, they can go rancid. Chop nuts and place in an airtight bag or container and freeze. Just scoop out what you need for your recipe and leave the rest in the freezer."], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 30, 2020"], "question_author": "Vita Lea", "view_list": [1, 27]}, "507": {"no_of_follower": 0, "respond_collected": 3, "name_list": ["Pearl Lederman", "Som Shubhra De", "Rana Bahadur Bhadel"], "question_title": "Can some one eat pineapple during cough?", "topic_list": ["Pineapples", "Coughing", "Fruit", "Eating", "Food", "Medicine and Healthcare"], "no_of_view": "356", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 0], "ans_list": ["i would ask your doctor about it", "You can but you may not !\nPineapple though very nutritious fruit and laden with Vitamin C, is vary tangy. The reason salt is so important in cooking, is that it has the ability to make food taste more like itself. Salt has been a trade item since ancient times so most areas without a local source would still have access to it. History of salt - Wikipedia\nBut with or without salt there are other preservative methods. Drying, smoking, pickling, freezing, fermenting, are examples.\nHow was food stored and preserved before the invention of refrigerators?\nThen there are foods like grains and nuts that can be kept for long periods without special preservation methods other than safe storage. Probably why the first crops were grains.\nGranary - Wikipedia", "The appropriately named Hallstatt culture of late Bronze Age, early Iron Age Europe was based in part on salt mining in the Austrian Alps.\nThe salt was mined with picks and placed into backpacks to be carried out.\nA backpack was discovered in an old collapsed mine from the region:\nThe Hall part of the name means salt and a neighbouring town is called Hallein. The German placename element Salz also means salt. The surrounding region was known as the Salzkammergut (salt producing region under direct control of the crown) during the middle ages and up to the modern period because of the all the salt mining. The Salzach river, itself meaning salt waterway, was where the salt was barged down to markets elsewhere. One of the towns that oversaw this trade was Salzburg which means salt fortress.\nAll this in the high mountains of central Europe.", "Smoking, drying and storing foods like grains and roots with a long storage time and just need to be dried.", "Smoking, drying, fermentation.\nPlus salt could often be obtained in the interior. Sometimes long trips would be made to the coast. Dry lake beds have a heavy salt buildup. Salt licks, salt springs", "Sea salt is only a part of the whole salt market, and always was. Inland, there are brine pools and salt flats, providing easily accessible salt, and underground rock salt deposits can be actually mined like ore and coal \u2014 there are lot of salt mines in Europe. Later on, people learned to imitate the nature and started to pump water into underground salt bodies, collecting and evaporatig resulting brine \u2014 this allowed harvesting salt without expensive mining works.\nPS: An interesting fact \u2014 most uranium in the world is actually mined exactly like salt: by injecting a weak acid solution into the ore body, which dissolves the ore and is pumped back for recycling, where the ore is precipitated and is processed further, while the carrier solution is reused again and again.", "They smoked the meat. As long as you have followed correct starter method (thoroughly answered elsewhere on Quora), that lovely and healthy odor is the fermentation from a thriving yeast culture and that\u2019s the goal and is the \u201csour\u201d part of sourdough.\nIf you find it is a bit too sour, ensure you don\u2019t stir the top layer back into the starter before discarding - include it in the discard. My experience has been that top layer tells me I need to feed it differently or stir it more frequently or both.\nIf you want a stronger starter, stir it back in. Mango Idli:\nYou Will Need:\n1 cup of mango pulp\n1 cup of plain yogurt\n1 cup of grated coconut\n1 cup of Semolina\n1 cup of sugar\n1 Tbsp ghee (clarified butter)\n10 cashew nuts\nA pinch of cardamom powder\nHow To:\nHeat the ghee (clarified butter) in a pan and dry roast the semolina until it turns golden brown. Remove it from the heat and keep it aside.\nTake all the remaining ingredients except cashew nuts and grind to make a fine paste. Add the paste to the roasted semolina and mix well.\nAdd a pinch of cardamom powder. Grease an idli pan using ghee (clarified butter). Pour the mix into it and cook for about 20 minutes. Garnish with the cashews before serving.\n2. Ragi Halwa:\nYou Will Need:\n1 cup of ragi\n\u00be cup of jaggery\n1/4 cup of pure ghee (clarified butter)\n1 Tbsp of cardamom powder\n1 cup of coconut milk\nWater\n4 Cashew nuts\nHow To:\nSoak the ragi overnight in water.\nWash the ragi properly and drain the water. Grind it along with one cup of water so that you get a smooth paste.\nUse a muslin cloth to sieve the paste. It will help you remove any coarse pieces and use the fine ragi milk to make easy to digest baby food.\nIn a pan, add the ragi milk, coconut milk, jaggery, ghee (clarified butter) and cardamom powder. Let the mixture come to a boil and keep stirring continuously. Cook until the mix thickens.\nRemove it from the heat. Garnish with the cashew nuts before serving.\n3. Oats Pancake:\nImage: Shutterstock\nYou Will Need:\n2 Tbsp oats powder\n1 Tbsp besan (gram flour)\n\u00bd grated carrot\n\u00bd finely chopped onion\n\u00bd Tbsp of turmeric powder\nSalt and black pepper powder as per taste\n\u00bd Tbsp of coriander powder\nWater\nGhee (clarified butter)\nHow To:\nMix the onions and the carrots in a bowl. Add the oats powder, besan, and the remaining spices.\nAdd water to make a smooth paste. Keep it aside for ten minutes.\nMelt ghee (clarified butter) in a pan. Pour a ladleful of the mix into the pan.\nSlowly spread it out to make a pancake.\nCook until both the sides turn golden brown.\nDon\u2019t forget to try this tastiest Indian recipes for babies.\n4. Sweet Potato Dosa:\nImage: Shutterstock\nYou Will Need:\n75g sweet potato\n1 cup of dosa mix\n1 Tbsp of ghee (clarified butter)\nSalt as per taste\nFor the seasoning:\nChopped onions\nFreshly chopped coriander\nGrated carrots\nFor a sweet version:\n1 Tbsp jaggery\nHow To:\nWash the sweet potatoes and peel the skin. Chop them up into small pieces and grind them using a little water and salt.\nAdd the sweet potato to the dosa mix. If you are making the sweet version, add the jaggery to the mix. Stir well and keep it aside for some time.\nHeat the dosa pan and grease it with ghee (clarified butter). Pour the mix into the pan and spread it slowly to make a pancake. Add the vegetables on top. Cook until both the sides turn golden brown.\n5. Elaichi Wheat Porridge:\nImage: Shutterstock\nYou Will Need:\n40g wheat dalia\n20g roasted gram\n3 pods of elaichi (cardamom)\nWater\n1 Tbsp of Ghee (clarified butter)\n1 Tbsp of Jaggery\nHow To:\nDry roast all the ingredients separately in a pan. Grind them together to make a fine powder.\nAdd four spoonfuls of the porridge powder in a bowl.\nAdd 100 ml of hot water and mix to make a thick paste.\nAdd ghee (clarified butter) and stir well.\nLet the porridge cool to room temperature before feeding your baby.\nDid you ever try this kinds of Indian food for babies?\n6. Beetroot And Potato Puree Recipe:\nImage: Shutterstock\nYou Will Need:\nHalf peeled and cubed potato\nHalf peeled and cubed beetroot\nHow To:\nPlace the vegetables in a bowl and put it inside a pressure cooker that contains water. Cook it for two to three whistles. Remove from the heat and keep it aside.\nOnce the steam releases, you can blend the vegetables in a food processor. Serve the vegetable puree to your baby.\n7. Methi Dosa:\nYou Will Need:\n1 bowl of raw rice\n1 Tbsp of methi (fenugreek seeds)\n\u00bc bowl of poha (flattened rice)\n1 Tbsp of jaggery\nA pinch of turmeric powder\nSalt as per taste\n1 Tbsp of Butter\nHow To:\nSoak the rice, methi seeds, and the poha overnight in lukewarm water in separate bowls.\nIn the morning, grind all the soaked ingredients along with the jaggery to make a smooth paste.\nAdd turmeric powder and salt to the mix. Stir well.\nHeat the dosa pan and add butter to grease it. Pour the mix into the pan and make a pancake. Cook until both sides of the dosa turn golden brown.\nStay Home Stay Safe and Healthy."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Shweta Sharma", "view_list": [5, 102]}, "11": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Sarath Nair K", "Kaamesh Peri", "Jaka Gl Stan", "Henry Nichols"], "question_title": "What does a halal certified product mean?", "topic_list": ["Halal Food", "Food"], "no_of_view": "611", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 1, 0], "ans_list": ["Halal certification is a must if you are planning to sell your products in the muslim world. In aseptic processing the product and the package are sterilized separately and then combined and sealed in a sterile atmosphere. That is why it can be kept for a long time without refrigeration.\nWhere is pouch milk is packed in HDPE film pack, which does not have barriers, hence milk spoils in 2\u20133 days.", "[1] Please refer this answer as well to have a clear understanding of the product\nBoth of the said product goes through different processing and packing conditions. From the technological point of view, pouch milk is merely a pasteurized milk wherein milk gets heat treated round about 80 degree centigrade and being hold at that temperature for 16 seconds and immediately chilled to 4 degree centigrade temperature followed by packing under the Form Fill Seal Machines and stored. The pasteurization process effectively kills the bacterial load present in the raw/incoming milk to a safe level (under 20000cfu/ml SPC count). Basically, these counts would tend to increase and multiply in certain folds when temperature abuse take place during transportation or storage. By the time you receive this pouch milk and store it in your refrigerator count would have increased to somewhere 50000 cfu/ml due to cold chain breaks and thus such milk ideally should be consumed within a day or two. Essentially, needs to be refrigerated all the time to ensure these increase counts do not multiply and curdled the milk. Refrigeration temperature would reduce the growth of bacterial multiplication. Only certain type of psychrophilic bacteriawould tend to grow at a very little rate at this controlled refrigerated temperature.\nComing to the point of tetra pack milk, the processing of milk takes place at a very high temperature of 140 degree centigrade and being hold at this temperature for 1 second. This process called as High Temperature Short Time (HTST) essentially employed for the milk expected to have longer shelf life. This high temperature and time combination kills every single bacteria in the milk (sometimes spores too) and render the milk with absolute zero count. This doesnt end here. After practicing above method, the milk necessarily have to go through stringent and enclosed packing process wherein ascetic filling into the tetra pack (6 layer packaging material) is carried out. This highly innovative packaging form ensures close to zero transmission of bacteria from outer side. Thus, such milk would tend to be stable even at normal temperature until the barriers in the tetra pack material starts to wear out and let the environmental load into the container.\nNot to mentioned while one renders the increased shelf life with advancement in process and packaging, it also negatively affects the nutritional availability of certain minerals and vitamins along with the freshness.\nFootnotes\n[1] Pratik's answer to Does Mother Dairy's Live Lite Milk have a lot of preservatives for rendering to be stored without refrigeration for 90 days?"], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Shri Vishwa Prasad Singh", "view_list": [19, 5, 49, 20]}, "31": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 5, "name_list": ["Jed McCann", "Doug Yensan", "Dave Keough", "Daniel Murphy", "Jake Guthmiller"], "question_title": "Now that Trump has demanded that food/meat processing plants reopen while with thousands of workers having to work next to other infected workers, shouldnt Trump reward all those workers with legal immigration status since most are illegal?", "topic_list": ["Trump Immigration Policies (2017-)", "Immigration Policy", "Illegal Immigration", "Trump Administration (2017-Present)", "Immigration to the United States of America", "Immigration", "Donald Trump (politician, business person)", "Politics of the United States of America", "Food", "The United States of America"], "no_of_view": "2,151", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [0, 0, 3, 1, 2], "ans_list": ["If the Trump administration is going to grant employers immunity from the consequences of their unsafe workplaces, and Republican governors are going to deem employees who refuse to return to work because their workplace is unsafe as ineligible for unemployment insurance benefits, then maybe we should do a little something to benefit those workers. It is like, \u201cI don\u2019t know what I\u2019m doing, this is the first time\u201d, and any thing comes out.\nPicture of one of the pullet eggs from my chickens above:\nEggs come in all sizes. The eggs get larger and the chickens lay less frequently as they get older (4\u20135 years is old). When they go into molt or when they start or stop laying the eggs can be very small and very large, some with two or even three yolks. There is a chart in this link:\nChicken egg sizes - Wikipedia", "They are graded by weight. A hen normally lays eggs within a few grams of each other. Occasionally one will be a size up or down. This does not usually happen. However, as a hen gets older she will lay fewer (and a little smaller) eggs.", "Egg size is determined both by the age of the hen and the breed of the hen. The farmer controls the ultimate egg size by choosing which breeds of hens he wants but all pullets (young hens) start laying smaller eggs and as the hen ages the egg size increases. Unfortunately as that happens the number of eggs laid by each hen decreases.\nRight now I have pullets hatched last fall and they are laying numerous small/medium sized eggs while my older hens lay jumbo sized eggs.\nSex links such as ISA browns, red star, golden comets or Cinnamon queens usually lay larger eggs to start and within a short time are laying eggs in the extra large to jumbo size.\nThe downside is that these hens can easily lay upwards of 300 eggs per year and are usually excellent layers for a year and a half or so then like all hens their production rate will drop.\nUsually that is the time the factory farms and production breeders get rid of them.\nI keep a small farm flock where a hen has a home for life so I get to see all the egg sizes and stages."], "date_list": ["Apr 30, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020", "Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Rose Anne Campbell", "view_list": [30, 237, 69, 31, 109]}, "598": {"no_of_follower": 2, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "How is pizza in Italy different from other parts of the world?", "topic_list": ["Culture of Italy", "Italian Food and Cuisine", "Pizza", "Country Comparisons", "Italy", "Europe", "Cooking", "Countries of the World", "Visiting and Travel", "Food"], "no_of_view": "155", "create_time": "Apr 29, 2020", "upvote_list": [], "ans_list": [], "date_list": [], "question_author": "Sri Harsha Bammidi (\u0c36\u0c4d\u0c30\u0c3f \u0c39\u0c30\u0c4d\u0c37\u0c3e \u0c2c\u0c2e\u0c4d\u0c2e\u0c3f\u0c21\u0c3f)", "view_list": []}, "740": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 4, "name_list": ["Michael Schwarz", "Mike DiGirolamo", "Andrew Boyd", "Bruce Newman"], "question_title": "As a Catholic, have you ever accidentally eaten meat on a Friday? If you want to start your journey to having a better body to feel great, here are some tips:\n1. Exercise Daily\nExercise daily for at least an hour. You do not have to kill yourself from running, jogging, etc., but you should have some sort of moderate physical activity in your everyday life. If you're looking to shed a few pounds fast, do a higher-level intensity workout. For example, go on a walk at a brisk pace for an hour. Or, you can jog and set certain intervals to sprint during that hour. Make sure you're not in severe pain during your workout. Just a warning, your muscles will ache after a high intensity workout. It may be irritating, but that means your body is changing for the better. Be sure to stay hydrated, stretch, and eat foods with a decent amount of protein after each workout. The protein will help keep your muscles, not fat, rebuilding.\n2. Sugar from candy will not help you get in shape. Even if it's just a single candy bar, one will eventually lead to another. Fruits and vegetables are the best thing to eat when getting into shape. Apples, for example, do a good job at making the stomach feel full for up to 3 to 4 hours. Green vegetables such as green beans and broccoli keep the digestive system clean and running.\nAlso, stick to lean meats like turkey and chicken. Seafood, such as, shrimp, and tilapia are also great alternatives. These foods are full of protein and healthy nutrients to help keep muscles fit and ready for workouts. In addition, be sure to portion what you eat. Having a good metabolism comes from portioning meals. Try to plan out eating six times a day and setting smaller portions, rather than having three large meals throughout the day. This will also help you find yourself breathing smoother when working out rather than huffing and puffing for air. Naturally you are asking yourself, how does the PC muscle relate to lasting longer in bed? The PC muscle is actually the muscle responsible for releasing semen during ejaculation. Thus, when the PC muscle stays in a relaxed state, it prevents you from reaching ejaculation.\nKeeping the PC muscle in a relaxed state during sex is not difficult, however it is something that needs to be worked on. Similar to your other muscles, the stronger they are, the easier it is for those muscles to relax in the face of pressure. Only when the pressure gets a little too much will the muscles get forced to leave its relaxed state. The IC muscle compresses the root of the corpus cavernosum, one of the penile erectile bodies (the penis has three erectile bodies: two corpora cavernosa and one corpus spongiosum, through which the urethra passes). The BC compresses the root of the corpus spongiosum and the urethra, and these muscles assist in the expulsion of urine and semen during ejaculation. The corpora cavernosa and the corpus spongiosum are separate erectile chambers, and erection is triggered by the surrounding muscles. They are also relatively safe from detrimental side effects as long as they are consumed in normal amounts.\nDopamine and serotonin are two hormones naturally produced by your body. However, when it comes to sexual endurance, dopamine will help you last longer, while serotonin may exacerbate premature ejaculation.\nResearch indicated that the brain secretes a burst of serotonin after ejaculation. This results in a decline in sexual excitement and erectile ability. When serotonin level slowly dissipates, erectile ability returns. While there are drugs that can act as serotonin inhibitor, you can minimize or eliminate serotonin\u2019s undesirable effect during intercourse by consuming a high-protein, low-carbohydrate meal before sex.\nPhenylethylamine and phenylalanine: High-protein meals contain more phenylethylamine and phenylalanine (an amino acid), which serves to reduce serotonin. Phenylalanine tablets are also available for this purpose. Other foods that contain phenylethylamine include salami and chocolate, though you should avoid chocolates that are high in sugar as it actually increases serotonin. Chocolates also contain the libido-boosting methylxanthines.\nGinseng and Vitamin B6: People have been using natural herbs like Panax ginseng, Maca root, green onions, aswagandha, ginger, honey, garlic, and the roots of Asparagus as libido-boosting tonics for centuries. While not all of them have clear benefits for premature ejaculation treatment, they do not result in undesirable side effects, so trying them out should not cause you any harm.\nGinseng\u2019s role in combating PE should no longer be in doubt. Both garlic and ginger enhances blood flow to men\u2019s penis, which helps in maintaining hard erection and combating PE. However, ginseng does a little more than that. During orgasm, we experience a surge in the hormone prolactin that serves to switch off sexual excitement. Similar to serotonin, the surge can be minimized, in this case by consumption of ginseng along with vitamin B6.\nMonounsaturated fat: Men whose diets are extremely low in fat (where fat comprises less than 10% of the calories in their diet) tend to have very low testosterone levels. Since testosterone level is incredibly important in sexual performance, it is a good idea to still consume healthy fat even when you are dieting. While I am no weight loss expert, most diet gurus right now advocate a balanced diet with proper macros ratio, so you should never skip on consuming fat anyway.\nTo increase testosterone production, consume monounsaturated fats that are found in olive oil, canola oil, red salmon, avocados, and nuts. As an aside, you should also get enough sleep as men with sleep apnea are also found to secrete abnormally low levels of testosterone during sleep.\nAntioxidants: Antioxidants are molecules that inhibit the oxidation of other molecules, terminating the production of free radicals that are bad for your health and your libido. Eating a good diet with sufficient antioxidants such as vitamins C and E will allow you to maintain not only good health (by reducing the risk of cancer and coronary heart disease) but longer intercourse sessions. Vitamin C is especially important in collagen production and reduction of stress. Incorporate leafy greens, citrus, and nuts such as almonds in your diet to boost your antioxidant level. If you find it difficult to get sufficient levels of antioxidants through diet alone, you may use antioxidant supplements, one of which is alpha-lipoic acid.\nGinkgo biloba: The herb ginkgo biloba can enhance nitric oxide production, which in turn improves arterial blood flow to the penis and allows for a strong erection. In addition, Ginkgo may restore sexual sensation and enhance libido. Ginkgo are also reported to increase penile size in the flaccid and erect state for some men, although I believe this is simply the effect of said increased blood flow to the penis. While this is rare, some people have reported that Ginkgo consumption results in headache, so if this is you, this food is not for you.\nL-arginine: L-arginine is an amino acid that has a beneficial influence on blood vessel health and nitric oxide action in the body, thus it may help with erectile dysfunction. As the blood vessels in a man\u2019s penis dilate, it increases blood flow to the region, which helps maintain an erection. Arginine also helps stimulate the secretion of growth hormones, removes ammonia from your body, and heals bodily wounds. L-arginine level can be increased by consuming protein-containing food. This includes quinoa, oats, soybeans, peanuts, walnuts, tuna, salmon, trout, tilapia, pork, beef, chicken, and dairy products. While it is hard to track the exact amount of L-arginine you consume, daily consumption of 56 grams of protein should be enough for men. Supplements are also readily available to boost your L-arginine level.\nCholine and Vitamin B5: While nitric oxide is one of the most crucial effectors of erection, there are other chemicals that are also vital in this process. One such chemical is acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that acts as a messenger carried by the nerves when the brain wishes to produce an erection. A mild elevation of acetylcholine can be achieved by ingesting foods that are rich in choline such as egg yolks, liver, and wheat germ, but choline supplements are also available. You can take choline supplements (1,000 to 3,000 milligrams) in conjunction with vitamin B5 (500 to 1,500 milligrams) for this purpose.\nMolybdenum: Molybdenum is an essential dietary trace mineral, and its deficiency can contribute to impotence. You can increase your Molybdenum levels by consuming food such as whole grain breads and cereals, liver, kidney, dark green leafy vegetables, and legumes. If you have weight loss goals, molybdenum is also something you do not want to miss, as it is involved in the utilization of carbohydrates and fats for the production of energy. It is also involved in the metabolism of iron and the prevention of tooth cavities. There also seems to be an association between molybdenum deficiency and esophageal cancer.\nPotassium: Similarly, potassium deficiency can cause impairment of arterial relaxation and decrease in testosterone production, which contributes to impotence and diminished libido. A lack of potassium is also linked with increased risk in hypertension. There are plenty of supplements that can provide you with enough potassium, but you can also satisfy your daily requirements by consuming dark leafy greens, baked potatoes, bananas, red salmon, mushroom, and avocados.\nZinc: Zinc is an essential mineral that is required to maintain a sense of smell, synthesizing protein, and keeping a healthy immune system. Zinc deficiency can lower testosterone production and cause impotence. Further, a lack of zinc may also increase estrogen. A study conducted in 1996 reported that zinc deficiency in rats reduces the number of androgen (testosterone or DHT) receptors but increases the number of estrogen receptors. Since an increase in the number of receptors increases the effect of a hormone (and vice versa), a zinc deficiency effectively increases estrogen levels and decreases androgen levels. Other symptoms of zinc deficiency range from hair loss, stunted growth, diarrhea, and a drop in immunity.\nA mild zinc deficiency is fairly common in Americans, although it is often more severe in the case of the elderly, alcoholics, and people who consume too much junk food. Almonds are rich in zinc and vitamin E, and it is touted to enhance libido and sexual desire as well. Other sources of zinc include seafood, lamb, beef, pork, chicken, spinach, and cashews. Consume them in reasonable amounts, as overconsumption may lead to headache and nausea."], "date_list": ["Apr 18, 2020", "Jan 20, 2020", "Jan 2, 2020", "Dec 5, 2019", "Nov 21, 2019", "Nov 15, 2019", "Nov 4, 2019", "Oct 11, 2019", "Mar 30, 2019", "Sep 1, 2018", "Aug 20, 2018", "Jan 8, 2018", "Oct 2, 2017"], "question_author": "Anonymous", "view_list": [21, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, 541, 187, 0, 0, 0]}, "255": {"no_of_follower": 1, "respond_collected": 0, "name_list": [], "question_title": "Hey! For example if you kept a few chickens or insects to clean up your food waste, that could be efficient.", "Historical tidbit: crickets and locusts are kosher.\nThe logic is that people must be able to eat these critters once those bugs at the crops, and it is an act of mercy to ensure the people don\u2019t starve.\nPeople may eat insects to get enough protein when their preferred sources are not available. Note that this means vegan/vegetarian isn\u2019t an option, because the main crops have failed or been consumed by insects.\nThere are places where insects remain on the menu because they\u2019re considered a delicacy. Telling them not to eat a traditional food is a cultural imposition. It is based on Western liberal secular environmentalist views that raise animals up to the status of sacred innocents. Never mind the literal cost they\u2019d pay in nutrition and income to live on a diet determined by European and American farming and industrial technology. Add the grated lauki and salt. Saute it on a medium flame till the lauki is cooked and fairly dry (all its moisture should be properly released and dried). Add the milk and bring everything to a boil . Reduce the heat and keep stirring intermittently until the mixture thickens. Mix in the sugar. Stir very well until it is dissolved. Cook for just about 5\u20137 more minutes on minimum heat. Add the raisins, nuts and cardamon powder. Mix well cover and leave just like that for about 5 minutes. I usually use two to four tablespoons of cornstarch in a cup of room-temperature beef broth to make a gravy with the rest of the broth (a carton of broth contains 32 oz of broth and I use the whole box) and some sauteed mushrooms and onions. I whisk it into the pot, add the hamburger steaks, and continue simmering to thicken it up. If there are leftovers and I put them in the refrigerator instead of the freezer, it may become gelatinous but it has never become solid. The gelatin will melt when you heat it up and you\u2019ll have thickened gravy again."], "date_list": ["Apr 29, 2020"], "question_author": "Diane Sanders", "view_list": [97]}, "807": cognitive ability to recognize negative side effects from mercury poisoning in themselves.\nOne way to avoid getting long-term damage from mercury poisoning is by getting regular tests to check for mercury levels and to stop exposing yourself to mercury if test results suggest that it\u2019s a good idea. Talk to your doctor about your mercury exposure so they can order the right tests.\nHowever, I know someone who did it that way, and avoiding sushi completely for several years until her mercury levels went back down wasn\u2019t fun. Instead, it\u2019s probably easier to replace regular consumption of high-mercury fish with low-mercury fish. For example, I find that ordering more salmon and less tuna is easier than just not having sushi at all.\nOf course, even if you shift to eating fish with less mercury, regular tests are still useful.
